text: The quintessential French bistro in Montreal. Still buzzing and still serving up classic french bistro fare.   As all the new restaurants in Montreal delight in serving ever more exotic dishes, L'Express stands out as a bastion of what a classic dinner in Montreal can be.

We came looking for a casual late dinner option for our first night in Montréal and we were not disappointed. We were offered and took a seat at the bar. There was a short 10 minute wait at 9pm (we should have called for a reservation prior to coming).  The main barman, an elderly gentlemen, took care of us. He gave us amazing recommendations for wine and food. We got the foie gras, duck confit and Toulouse Maison (house sausages); all of these were excellent. It was a great dining experience!

I didn't make a reservation but they still have a table for me (party of three). The dishes taste good and the waiters are friendly. It's noisy only because there were so many people inside, not because someone was shouting. We ate a lot of bread and pickle (taste good!) while waiting for the entree.

Food: 4/5
Service: 3.5/5
Cleanliness: 3.5/5
Price: $$$

The restaurant definitely needs a reservation - it's rather small and can only accommodate so many customers at once. L'Express has a large history behind the restaurant which can be seen on its restaurant walls: It seems that the restaurant group takes a wall portrait. The pictures date back to early 1980s which really surprised me.

The menu at L'Express is rather small - the three columns are in French / English / and Spanish or Italian ... I can't figure out the last column. Anyway, the prices are not listed on the menu so ask your waiter for prices, or have a look online on their website.

This is what we ordered:

Me:
Appetizer: Country Style Soup (Minestrone)
Main: Shrimp Risotto

Hubby:
Appetizer: Bone Marrow with Coarse Salt
Main: Veal Kidney in Mustard Sauce

Hubby took recommendations from our waiter who eagerly recommended the bone marrow and veal kidney as my husband is quite an adventurous eater. I would've loved to join him, but I decided to be safe and stick to shrimp risotto as I was pregnant.

After ordering, we were brought out condiments. Each table had a huge jar of cornichons (or are they gherkins?) which we were a little puzzled about at first. With no instructions on how or what to eat it with, we just waited until our appetizers arrived.

Hubby's bone marrow looked so appetizing! He definitely had a side of cornichons as well :D, and with the baked crostini, he told me that the bone marrow was delicious! Oh how I wish I could've had a bite! We thought the portions of bone marrow were very generous, as we had ordered bone marrow elsewhere and its portions were not very big at all, only bite size. It was our first restaurant (so far) that served whole pieces.

My minestrone soup was nothing out of the ordinary, but I really enjoyed it as I was pretty cold from the outside Winter weather (remember this was back in January). The soup definitely hit the spot and I finished the entire bowl without sharing with my husband :P. I was surprised at myself because I don't normally enjoy minestrone (I prefer creamier soups) but at L'Express, it was beyond my expectations.

Hubby's veal kidney arrived not too much later and at first, hubby enjoyed it very much. However, towards the end of his main dish, I think he was having a bit of trouble trying to finish it. It was creamier than we had expected, and the kidney were fattier portions of the veal. It truly was a French dish! The potatoes were definitely helpful in balancing the fattier flavours of the dish, but I don't think they were enough.

My shrimp risotto was delicious! The tables next to me kept looking over at my shrimp risotto... it was that good! The flavours were very well balanced and overall very flavourful! We couldn't really tell what the sauce consisted of but it's definitely worth reordering! It had generous portions of shrimp and other vegetables as well which I appreciated.

I'm a sucker for profiteroles and I'm always drawn to ordering them whenever I see them on the menu! The profiteroles at L'Express were heavenly, literally. It was so good that I had to stop myself to ordering another plate of them. The profiteroles were perfectly baked with a caramelized top- crispy on the outside while still soft on the inside while still being warm! The cold ice cream went perfectly with it and oh my goodness it really was heavenly. If you love sweet caramel like me, you'd definitely enjoy this dessert!
Overall, our dinner at L'Express was a very enjoyable one. I wish we had visited the restaurant earlier during our time in Montreal- we would've definitely been regulars! The service was slightly spotty - the restaurant was so crowded and busy that it took some time to get a hold of a waiter and put in our order. But the waiter that was in charge of our table was very friendly and helpful, and definitely didn't forget about us throughout our night. The restaurant, in my opinion, could've been a little cleaner, but with the wet winter weather and the number of customers in the restaurant, I think L'Express did a decent job of keeping the restaurant tidy and clean amidst everything.

In the end, our bill came to something near what we would pay at a higher priced ($$$) restaurant. I don't remember the exact numbers, but it wasnt anything outrageously expensive for the quality of food and experience we just enjoyed. We would highly recommend the restaurant to anyone - those visiting Montreal, locals looking for a new restaurant, those going out on a romantic date, family reunions, for late night eats especially as it's open until 2-3am! It's going to feel like you are transported to France for an authentic French meal.

Make a reservation because if you don't you will be told to wait an hour by a man who thinks he is better than you. The hostess made the experience so bad that when we came back to eat (came back for the time we were told and we still had to wait) the entire experience left a nasty taste in our mouths.  Don't bother wasting your time.

This place was fantastic.  It was so nice that my wife and I ended up here both days of our two day stay in Montreal.  The first visit was late night for a couple of drinks and a bite to eat.  The second visit was for a longer lunch.  On both visits we sat at the counter which was great.  The service was very good and it was actually really enjoyable to watch the staff at work.  The older man behind the bar late night was mixing up some great classic cocktails for us.  He was very nice and funny as well.

The food was delicious and felt simple and homey.  The best part of the place was just how relaxed it was.  It felt like you could relax there for as long as you wanted and you would never feel rushed or pressured to leave. This was such a nice change from New York where it sometimes feels like they are trying to turn the table over as soon as you sit down.  It was extremely comfortable here.  We will definitely be back on our next visit!

Their menu out front doesn't show it, but this restaurant also serves breakfast, which can be a lovely and inexpensive way to enjoy the ambiance of this special resto.

The breakfast menu is very simple fare, and everything is a la carte.  Choices include baguette, croissant, rillettes, slices of emmenthal cheese...  each range an average of around $2 - $4, and you just add up the ingredients you want on your breakfast plate.  If you're looking for creative combinations of eggs benedict, plates lavishly decorated with fruit or hangover-healing heavy doses of grease, this is not the place for you; potatoes don't even appear on the menu.  But the simple food they do they do very well.

If you're dining with a few others, I would suggest (as I will be doing next time) ordering plates of tomatoes, cheese and rillette to share along with your toast and eggs.  Otherwise, if you order it all for yourself, you'll be faced with the equivalent of one whole tomato, 6 slices of cheese for your modest - though perfect - slice of toasted baguette.

The fruit cup last saturday was especially nice - a pretty verrine of strawberries, oranges and grapefruit.

On a Saturday morning, it was packed; reservations are strongly recommended.

Tetes de violon, mackerel, pieuvre aux lentils (all three are appetizers) followed by risotto de homard and les rognons. The only disappointment was the risotto. Although I was pleasantly surprised at its lighter than usual consistency, I felt it was light on taste and the chef was heavy handed with the frozen mixed vegetables.

i looooooved this place. went in a big group and got wonderful service. i was very hungry and worried the portions would be mega-french style aka tiny portions. i was proven wrong!! really worth the prices here. 
i highly recommend the burrata salad. DELISH. i didn't love the lobster risotto but my partner didn't. the steak frites was also wonderful. 
one star off for me asking the waiter a recommendation for dessert and getting the apple tart - which was gross. no one at our table even touched it. they still charged us for it. oh well.

If you're looking for completely old school French bistro - take a seat.   A classic opener of marrow bones with coarse sea salt was positively unctuous. This restaurant has a well-deserved reputation for its steak tartare which was perfectly seasoned and  just a bit spicy. The poached  salmon was beautifully and simply cooked and them served atop chervil mashed potatoes surrounded by a classic lemon beurre blanc. 
Great food, knowledgeable staff, interesting wine list and a very nice selection of local cheeses to finish - all for a very reasonable price.
This is a great Montreal landmark and restaurant whether you are looking to show off great food to out of town guests or just looking for a "classic" night out.
Delicious food. I had veal which was cooked perfectly. It came with a delicious fresh salad. Great old fashioned vibe. Wonderful experience. Highly recommend.

This place was great.  We asked a stranger on the street for a lunch recommendation and she pointed out this place and said it was her favorite.  Walked in and the place was nearly empty.  They asked if we had a reservation and we almost left.  But they made room for us and 15 minutes later the place was completely full.  The food and service was excellent!  .  It has been over a year since we were there and we still think about it.  Highly recommend.

L'Express is an institution in Montreal, and in the words of our hotel concierge, they serve "very very traditional French" which I guess makes sense considering this is on St. Denis, which is apparently the more "French" side of the city.  Decor is a traditional French bistro with the ornate bar and the black and white checkered floor.  The food and service here are outstanding, and its no wonder this place is busy all the time.  Like many other places in Montreal (with the exception of L'Assommoire), this place did not have a cocktail list but I went with the Sidecar which was excellent, and served in one of those old tiny martini glasses that I love.  Again, like Club Chasse, would have ordered another if I only had the time. 

To start:
Arugula with gruyere 
Duck rillettes (duck liver pate) 

Entrees:
Wine: Pomerol Bordeux, 2005, Chateau Du Grande Chambellan (merlot/cab blend)
Special - Duck with figs -- duck was succulent, juicy, rich, expertly prepared.  Why am I not surprised?
Hanger steak with frites 

Dessert:
The dessert was, quite simply, out of this world and like no other dessert I've ever had.  Leave it to the French!  It was the Ill flotette au caramel and was like a crispy carmelized dome with merengue filling and in a creamy sauce with crispy waffle pieces on the side.  Absolutely amazing!  You must not miss this.  Have to order. 
Cafe Latte -- best latte of my life! I knew it would be incredible here, that's why I ordered it and it did not disappoint.  Wish I could eat here more often, I would love to try sooo many more things on the menu. 

Writer's note: I have a confession...I did not discover this amazing life changing dessert on my own.  I saw it in a YouTube video where some girl ordered it and knew I had to have it. Here's the link if you're interested...
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zqsfYS0snbU

Do not fill up on the bread and butter. Strongly recommend the steak tartare, and the foie gras is a must. My wife and I split those two dishes and we both left uncomfortably full. Wait staff is very helpful and made excellent wine pairing suggestions from their extensive wine list.

Gralhggha. That's the sound of me salivating over the thought of their bone marrow appetizer. It's sooooo good. Sinfully delicious hunks of bone marrow with crunchy toasts and coarse sea salt. That may have been the best thing I ate in Montreal.

I also had a very competent duck confit salad, while my friend had the beef tartare. Both were very tasty and well-executed, but neither was knock-your-socks-off amazing like the bone marrow. Mmmm, bone marrow...

The dessert, however, wasn't that great, even if it was a spectacle. We ordered the floating island, and when it came out, our server actually wished us luck in finishing it. It was giant. But the problem was that the island was encased in a hard shell of caramelized sugar which was overwhelming and not that tasty, and there wasn't much of an ocean for the island to float in. 

The service at this place was also great for the most part. Very smart and very professional, even though it was packed. I feel like I should also mention that my friend and I were clearly the youngest table that we could see. Granted, we're college students, and most other tables looked like older businessmen...

Saturday dinner for four, reservations booked about 5 days ahead. The place was still bustling when we left around ~12:15am. We were shown directly to our table when we arrived, with the waiter removing a "Reserved" sign from a table near the front windows of the restaurant. Ah, a good signal.

Service was snappy and on point, keeping everybody happy while not being over-obtrusive. We felt like we got a little attitude at the start (being four American males in their mid-20s), but the service warmed up quickly. Recommendations were excellent and the waiters were knowledgeable about both the dishes and the drinks. 

For appetizers, we had the rillette, chicken liver mousse, ouefs in mayonnaise, and a good cheese salad. As a devotee of salty meat and fat, I got down mainly on the rillette and the mousse. The rillette was rustic and flavorful, with a chopped texture that had just enough creaminess to allow you to spread it over toast. A rich, gamey pork. The mousse was probably the highlight of the meal; one of the best dishes I've had in a long time. An ethereal, fluffy emulsion of savagely herbacious fat. God, I love it. I did not sample the other dishes since we had a vegetarian with us, and I did not want to eat his appetizers, but he had nothing but good things to say. I will also point out that they were very accommodating, making many suggestions to him.

Dinner was the duck confit over a salade verte. While the duck was spectacular, with wonderful contrasts between the creamy meat and crispy edges, I was most surprised by the greens. Fresh, flavorful, high-quality greens can bring a salad into another stratosphere. These slightly bitter, crispy greens, dressed lightly in duck fat, were perfect.

We had the creme caramel and maple syrup tart for dessert. The creme caramel was mediocre, with a kind of flabby quality. Not much flavor in the sauce, either. The tart was delicious, but I thought the crust was a bit dry and crumbly.

Dinner for four with three courses, two bottles of wine, digestifs, taxes, and tip was $270. A fantastic meal. Well-executed, classic bistro fare served with no frills or attitude, with great service.

Service was EXCELLENT!!! The food was ok..... I had the quiche. It was ok but it was buried under a mountain of green salad that lacked flavour.... You could feed 3 cows off the amount of salad that overflowed my plate that made for disappointing presentation --- it also lacked flavour as the "dressing" was just olive oil. But what they lacked in food the they made up for in their excellent service.... Our waiter was fantastic.

Still one of my absolute faves for bistro food in MTL. Food is v solid, service is pretty good (okay, not great) and prices are full but not outrageous with US$/Cdn$ exchange rate right now. Pretty amateur hour that they jam parties of three onto a two top, but at least they seem to be consistent with that (crappy, screwed up) policy.

Excellent, excellent meal.  I love Montreal, it's one of my favorite cities and in all my trips I couldn't believe I hadn't been here.  We started with the delicious bone marrow and I had the quail which was perfect.

Serve was very pleasant, and very French, but I like that.

Great service and ambiance, awful food the one time I've eaten here. The chicken with mustard sauce was bland; the sorrel(?) potage was unimpressive. The butter was too cold to spread, and the bread just average bread. 

Might give it another try, but only because of all the other glowing reviews here.

Very French bistro with excellent food.  Be prepared to practice your French (if you wish) or ask for the English print out of the menu. I had the homemade raviolis (raviolis maison) which were delicious with mushrooms on the top. My husband enjoyed the fresh salmon. We topped it off with the Chocolate tart (tarte au chocolate). Very dense with a deep dark chocolate taste, which was delicious if you love dark chocolate.  Oui, would highly recommend but make reservations.

Best French late night bistro for a sexy first date (bring someone you want to impress/get into bed) Or simply go by yourself, they have a bar counter. Huge selection of wine and food. Authentic French bistro feel. Knowledgeable staff. I love the bone marrow, steak frite, lobster bisque and they give u delicious warm bread with delicious fresh butter and a jar of pickles! Their desert are very good as well. Fairly priced for the quality. Went about 5 times.. It never fails. Their consistency is unmatched. Their menu has been the same for years now. Expect to pay 40$/person if frugal or around 60$ +/person for let's say a 3 course meal with a glass of wine. Hope you go enjoy!

L'Express is your classic French bistro, and nothing less. The service is the best you can get. They have an extensive menu with classic dishes such as tartare. Everything they make is simple but perfectly executed and this is why they maintain a 5-star rating, year after year. I cannot even recommend specific menu items because everything on the menu is perfect and beautiful, simple and classic. No experimentation here. The basics, and the basics done well. There aren't some items that are better than others. Go in, sit down, and enjoy every bite of whatever you may order!

I am so glad that I don't have to deal with going to Paris to experiance this level of gastronomy.  Every bad review I have read about this place seems to come from people who claim to be New Yorkers - I haven't put a connection yet as to why but for the moment if your mail gets sent to zip code 10001 through 10282 and you summer on hampton beach, you might want to stay away from this place or risk comparing it to all the way more fabulous places in Tribeca and Soho.  All kidding aside L'Express is everything that it should be and nothing that it should'nt. On the two ocasions I have been service has been phenominal both from servers and bartenders.  That was also one of the chief complaints about this place - I haven't experianced it and I don't see how unless it was busy and someone was camping out and not realizing it.  Lets get to brass tacks... Food - Phenominal! Best Steak frites in Montreal, excellant thick hanger steak cooked to perfection (seared on the outside and mooing on the inside) with a rich herb butter: frites were also amazing, medium cut not to thin not too thick and not greasy at all.  Salad was perfect as an app and I was able to try the Ravioli of the day (house made) and it too was perfection.  So far I have only tried one wine on their list and thats all I have to.  One of the bartenders put me on to Brunel De La Gardine 2007 Cotes Du Rhone - modestly priced but it breaks the mold for young Cotes Du Rhone (in my humble opinion).  They tell me that there is an exclusive agreement between express and the Brunel house in France - meaning this isnt available anywhere else in N.America, currently I spend my time on the internet and in wine shops around the tristate area trying to make that NOT SO. Back to topic - For Dessert they have the typical brassarie faire of truffles and flans, my table elected the Chocolate truffles sold individually.  The concentrated chocolate flavor of one was enough to satisfy me as a molton chocolate cake, with alot less fuss.  A few things to think of before you go.. make a reservation because they are busy every night; get the bone marrow because they ran out of it last time I was there and I know it must be good;  go for wine, because liquour pours are typically measured as is standard in Montreal; try to get a drink at the bar and chat up the staff and bartenders - they are very friendly and helpful, even so far as to recomend other resturants for your trip. I love this place and I want to sublet a table for an entire summer!

The food was exceptional here. Classic French food. Ever dish was impeccably executed. For starters, we had the chilled asparagus. For the main, we had a delicious lamb shank and the duck confit salad. Dessert was apple pie, French style. 

While the food was excellent, I found our waiter to be rude and inattentive.

I loved this place so much that I decided to share with the world the goodness that is L'express. Went here recently at the ungodly hour of 11:30 pm and feasted on the bone marrow, oeufs mayonnaise, cold asparagus soup, and lobster risotto, complemented by one of the cheaper red wines, a Cote du Rhone (chateau des vieux or something like that? 2009), which was surprisingly yummy. The service was very professional, the ambiance was lovely. An unforgettable meal. Thank you L'express! Thank you Montreal!
Love this place! This is the place why I love Montreal! Love the atmosphere and foods are great. Nice server:)

Perfectly executed old-school french bistro. Classy and sophisticated but not stuffy. Clearly popular as the place was quite crowded by the time we left. Reservations probably required.  We arrived early with younger kids and they were perfectly polite and friendly. Would probably be harder with children later in the evening, but that's true anywhere.

Raw oysters and celery rouemalade for starters. Oysters were salty and fresh. Roumalade was light and almost creamy (though no cream in it.) Duck confit salad, duck "steak" with figues, a hanger steak frites, and country vegetable soup for main courses. All done to a tee and couldn't be improved. The steak frites was truly standout for an old standby. And the duck with figs rich and flavorful for a winter night.  Soup was a thinner broth based one, in a classic french style. Not super hearty but flavorful. Desserts were a dense dark chocolate torte and an exquisite ile flotant with the whipped egg whites covered in a dome of crystalized caramel. Both exceptional!

A demi of red Languedoc wine complemented it all quite well and was reasonably priced. Well worth a visit for french bistro food done as it should be.

This is our go to French style bistro restaurant right out of Paris. 

L'express is an institution in Montreal. It can be very hard to get seats especially at the weekend. Don't hesitate to sit at the bar.

The food is varied , excellent and while not cheap represents great value for money. All the staff are very pleasant and knowledgeable about everything on the menu both food and wine. Do not hesitate to ask which wine do you recommend for the dish you choose.

We have had almost everything on the menu. Having done so we always find ourselves coming back to the bones and the octopus with lentils for starters. For main course I can't resist the veal kidneys mushroom sauce.

The desserts are also to die for. Again choose anything you can't go wrong.

I think I have been reluctant to write about this place for so many years because it is so good I almost don't want more people to know about it. It is already tough enough to get a seat last minute.

Say thank you David, for giving this one up!

Tried our luck without reservations any luckily they were able to fit us in (party of two) but we had to leave by a certain time which was not a problem.  Point being, make reservations!

The service was very attentive and patient as I attempted to converse solely in French (they do speak English.)  This is what I was expecting when I have French Bistro.  The service was great and anticipated every need, the atmosphere so very french, the food -- a traditional bistro style.  A very good wine list, limited number of demi- bottles, no beer. 

My husband had the quail and I had the shrimp risotto which both were good-- but not earth shatteringly fantastic.  What was great was the little jars of cornichon pickles and spicy (like clear your sinuses mustard) at every table. 

And again, the service was so attentive, it made the average meal so much more special.  They do take Amex Ex

Super restaurant.
Le service était impeccable et l'ambiance plus que conviviale.
Typique bistro français. Nous y étions un mercredi soir et le restaurant était plein.

La carte des vins est impressionnante et on adore le pot de pickles sur la table!
J'ai mangé l'os à moelle en entrée et pris le tartare en plat principal. Clairement le meilleur tartare que j'ai eu l'occasion d'essayer. Enfin un endroit où ils ne gorgent pas la viande de mayo!

Je recommande fortement le resto et n'oubliez pas de réserver!

Very good, close to my hotel in Holiday Inn Mid- town, $8 CAD cab ride. 

Ordered: 

- Half bottle red wine, very good. 
- Foie Gras, good and not as oily as the I tried in SF. Enough for 4 people 
- Steak Tartare, good and fresh. 
-Quail with wild rice, juicy and flavorful. 

Would go again.

L'Express is located in a neighborhood filled with some of Montreal's best restaurants. The outside of the building certainly doesn't stand out but it was already packed when I got there for lunch. The portions were big for one person. I enjoyed the duck confit salad but I had to share the bone marrow since it was too rich for me. 4 stars.

I showed up solo on a Friday night, with no reservation, hoping to get a spot at the bar, which was full with "reserve" tags. Luckily the staff accomodated me with the condition that I wrap up before 7:30. I could not refuse that!

I had the chicken liver pâte with pistachios, pot au feu, a couple glasses of wine, and some conversation with other customers...fantastic...very helpful staff, suggested the menu items. Oh, the cornichons are really good, too!

No doubt I will return to L'Express whenever I can make my way back to Montréal.
Delicious food. We had the chicken and salmon and it was AMAZING. The restaurant feels very Parisian and the wait staff was friendly. Definitely what we wanted from a french restaurant in Montreal.
Very classy, excellent french cuisine. The service is A+. Very knowledgeable about the wine. Went twice. Great for 2-4 people. No loud music. Be prepared to pay a good amount though!

Let's begin with a day spent at Atlanta's Hartsfield Int'l because of a canceled flight to Montreal and end here at L'express. On the recommendation of a friend, I found myself shimmying up to the bar at this restaurant in a pretty hip - albeit understated at night anyway - part of town. I made a reservation just in case, but was delighted to see several empty spots at the bar. Hy (pronounced Ee) immediately introduced himself and made a wine recommendation based on my mood, and once the meal was selected, suggested another to suit the palate. The meal was fantastic - truly. Having spent the previous weeks in Vegas and New Orleans, I feel qualified to say this. Hy recommended the fiddlehead fern to start and the lobster risotto, both specials in season. I'd never had fiddleheads and was delighted to devour a dish of almost tender asparagus-like tendrils in a delicately scented light cream sauce that was rounded out with bits of ham and slivers of toasted almonds. I could have called it a night after this dish but decided to stay for the main course - a risotto of sweet lobster and a confetti of zucchini, red pepper and tender peas. Once the plate was cleared, I asked Hy for an after dinner drink suggestion in place of dessert and we decided on his first idea, a viscous, sweet wine with a nutty finish. Dinner complete, a list of personal recommendations for other restaurants and place to check out in Montreal from him, I was sleepy with thoughts of what and where to dine next. 

*On a side note, I read with interest about someone's butter comment. Indeed, the butter at L'express is remarkably good and I'm ashamed to admit, I slathered it on quite think to the equally delectable bread. Perhaps the calories are better spent on one of the restaurant's myriad specialties though.

Went here about 7 years ago. A truly memorable meal of quail. I don't really have the finances to patronize every upscale restaurant around, but for me this was probably the best meal I ever had. Montreal is so romantic.

excellent, unpretentious French comfort food in a classic bistro setting. reserve at least a day in advance as the place is packed.

the bone marrow appetizer and the two mains of kidney and quail were perfection on a plate. service was efficient and friendly, the server translated everything skillfully

My boyfreind snd I love thid place!when we want good french cuisines we come here! The tartar is hand cut wich is very important. The pasta is homemade .. i love the set up of the restaurant snd the floors.. you really feel  like your in france .. the waiters are very nice & so is the clientele. If your looking for a good supper with freinds ,first date.. you name it , its the place to be.

Coming from DC where Le Diplomate is all the rage, I was excited to try an excellent French spot with a great reputation...where I could actually get reservations. 

Everything here thrilled me. I love that this is a nice French place, but it is not pretentious. The atmosphere is upscale casual, emphasis on the casual. Our waiter was very attentive and was happy to answer our questions. The service, from the host, to the waiter, to the busers, was spot on throughout the night. 

We started with the special mushroom tart, which we split, and it was everything a good tart should be. The pastry was buttery and flaky, with that great browned taste. The cheese was savory, but subtle, and the mushrooms were an excellent balance to the rest of the tart. 

For mains, I had the house made ravioli, which has pork and veal with a mushroom glaze. The waiter did make sure that I was okay doubling up on mushroom dishes, which was a nice catch, but I was happy to have both and the flavors were distinctly different. The boyfriend had the special lobster risotto. The raviolis were incredible, the pasta was doughy and tender, the filling was so flavorful and savory, and the mushroom glaze was to die for. It had this deep, earthy flavor and I sopped up the rest with the amazing crusty bread. The lobster risotto was an excellent summery counterpoint. From what I saw on the boyfriend's plate and tried, the flavors were light, the lobster was generous, and he was practically licking his plate even though he said it was very filling. 

For dessert we split the chocolate tart. Of course the tart was a dense, intensely chocolatey experience, but the dark chocolate sauce that adorned it really made the dish. It was so dark and a little bit bitter that it made the tart even better. The crust was nice and thin, so it held together and had a nice butter flavor, but didn't get in the way. 

I ate here two days ago and I am still raving about it. It is not to be missed in Montreal.
Lively French bistro with excellent food.  We made a large order, and everything we ordered was good.

I almost hate to review this place, because so many people have given it a 5-star rating, and my experience was definitely less than par.

I'll keep it short: people clearly pay for the ambience (i.e., wonderfully traditional French bistro, where you can linger for hours, drinking wine and/or coffee, and enjoy some good food.) The meal was okay (steak frites), but I've had better for less.

If you're in town for a few days and want to give it a go, shoot for mid-to-late afternoon in between the lunch & dinner rush, and you may be able to get in without a reservation. If you're aiming for a dinner seating, book ahead a few days (at least).

Very good food here!

We had the fish soup and salmon tartare as appetizer. Then we had the beef chicken stew and sea bass as main course.

Everything was amazing and waiters were attentive!

I have a friend who acts as though every piece of food that enters her mouth has been a gift from the gods. She closes her eyes. She moans. It's quite the sight to witness (aka laugh at). I mean, I LOVE food, but I have never had that type of spiritual experience that she seems to always have.

That is, until I had the steak at L'express. Something came over me. I felt like Sally in When Harry Met Sally (but without the whole faking thing). Now it was my friend's turn to laugh at me. But you know what? I don't even care! That steak. Damn that steak. I will never forget you.

Came here with an out of town friend because we wanted an authentic Montreal bistro experience. From the moment we walked through the doors and were promptly escorted to our table we experienced nothing short of fabulous service. I ordered the sorrel soup and mushroom ravioli. The sorrel soup was so sorrely and smooth. Very green, delicious addition and not too rich. The mushroom ravioli was a real hit. Wonderful thin pasta in a glorious sauce. I sopped up as much as I could with the bread I saved to do just that. We couldn't resist truffles and coffee to round it all off. And under 50$ are you kidding me? Very reasonable prices for such a great meal.

This restaurant has a unique and beautiful interior and absolutely wonderful professional service! Ever so many good wine choices and the food was incredible. I got the Quail with Wild Rice and my husband got the Steak, both were delicious. Overall experience was a definite 5 star.

A fabulous bistro with perfect French fare, great wines by the glass menu, and the best cafe creme this side of Paris. We sat at the bar and enjoyed our waiter's attentiveness.

I can't wait to eat here again (and again).

It's not bad, but its reputation is clearly greater than the actual restaurant. The food is pretty good, although can get downright below average when there are a lot of people there. The service sucks at times, other times excellent. Depends how busy they are.

The decor is cute and the location is decent. 

Overhyped is the best descriptor for this place.

This is my favorite place to eat in Montreal. There are meals that are easy to appreciate and appeal to simpler palates (like the delicious hangar steak),  and more adventurous but no less tasty (like the bone marrow). I like to eat at the bar,  and I have always found the staff professional,  knowledgeable,  and very polite and fast. I always trust my waiter's advice on meals and wine,  and they never lead me wrong. 

I've seen some reviews saying people read other reviews and expected more and consequently were disappointed.  I'd like to ask: what,  exactly,  where you expecting? If you expected an orgasm in your mouth and a super cheap bill,  you may be disappointed indeed.  But for consistently great classic French food,  served by knowledgeable staff in a cozy bistro,  this is your place. It's not as cheap as eating at a restaurant in my hometown,  but then again,  I've never eaten food this great in my hometown,  and I'm happy to splurge to eat and drink well. 

My tips: get reservations,  try a couple different appetizers (I love the pate!) and go for a dessert.  Enjoy!

Came here after we got denied at Au Pied du Cochon for not having a reservation. This is as classic French bistro as you are going to get. Solid French food, nothing fancy, but they excel at every dish they do. Had the Hanger Steak with frites and it was good. Nothing to drool over - a solid steak. Also had the duck confit and that was tender and full of flavor and came on a bed of greens. Appetizers were a mayo egg and chicken pate, which is highly recommended. Skipped dessert. A solid meal that reminded me of Parisian bistros visited in 2004.

Stopped here after reading the excellent reviews and I have to say this place wasn't even satisfactory. Overrated and may even be a tourist trap. I had the quail/wild rice - drenched in some sauce and the rice wasn't cooked properly. If I were to ever go back I'd probably order something less easy to botch off the menu, like the ravioli

L'express is the most quintessential Resturant in Montréal. It perfectly encapsulates what dining in this city is, and should be. From the second you walk in the door, you feel like you're in France. The food is killer - specifically the ravioli. I have dreams about the ravioli. Very good prices. Impressive staff. Great private import wine selection (with prices for every budget). This is a place I will come to time and time again. After moving here 3 years ago for school - this is one resturant that has been one of my all time favourites.

Delicious, simple meal; attentive waitstaff; cool 1930s-esque ambiance.  

I had the sauteed duck confit with salad, and my boyfriend had the homemade raviolis.  The duck confit salad was fresh, delicious, and plenty for an entree.  Greens, sauteed green beans, radishes, bits of crunchy ham or canadian bacon, mini croutons, and a light vinaigrette.  I've been craving it ever since, and will probably attempt to recreate it soon, but I'm sure it won't live up to my memory.  The ravioli were light and tasty, filled with a mixture of pork and beef, I think, and surrounded in what looked and tasted like a beef or pork broth of some sort. We finished up with the orange creme caramel.  Everything was absolutely delicious.  

Plus, they bring a pickle jar to your table after you order.  Blissful!

While the restaurant seems fancy, the people are generally unpretentious and the food is delicious. The steak tartare is HUGE, finely minced and delicious. They give you a big jar of cornichons to go with it which is oddly satisfying. The bone marrow is a must and I like how they cut the bone sagittally instead of lengthwise. Steak and frites were delicious as expected as well. Have gone here many times and will definitely go again.

the ambience is very French bistro (probably why it's called that!) with typical French food and excellent wine menu.  They had a lot of wines by the glass and there were many reasonable options.  We ordered:
- Foie gras - absolutely delicious.  It was so fresh and creamy and light.  The best foie gras I've ever had
- Bone marrow - I love bone marrow, but this was a bit disappointing.  I don't know what it is.... It was healthy portion and it was prepared very simply, which I like, but something about it didn't blow me away.
- Quail with wild rice - Quail was perfectly cooked and crispy and the wild rice was really "wild" rice, not some fake version.  Seasoning was perfect
- Pork and sausage ravioli with sherry sauce - reviews said their ravioli is really good because it's homemade, but I didn't really see anything special about it. Maybe I'm spoiled from all the NY Italian cooking, but I thought this ravioli was just good, not excellent.  Nothing about it was bad.  In fact, it was really quite delicious, but it just didn't blow me away.

My favorite bistro in all of Montreal. 
From the great hors d'oeuvres to the fabulous deserts, this is a spot you just can't afford to miss. 
Located in the French quarter, l'express is a small restaurant that is lays packed and full of eclectic people.
The food is amazing but be sure to order l'ile flottante before they sell out and don't forget the cheese and wine to finish off the evening.

Absolutely awesome.  Had a full dinner here. soup to nut.... delicious.  And not that expensive for a full meal (app, entree, dessert, wine)... Went with 3 other people.  came to $35 a head tip included. 2 Bottles of wine and 2 shared desserts.  Must make reservations!

I had a delicious poached salmon with chirvil mashed potatoes.  It was delicious.  We started off with a creamy chilly gazpatcho which was wonderful. Matched with a nice glass of rose and a lovely waitress.

I am a HUGE fan of this restaurant.  Visits to Montreal absolutely suck unless they include a meal here.  

I am addicted to the Mouse de foie de voillaie appetizer.  Pure sex in a ramekin.   It's a mix of various fowl livers topped with pistachio's served with fresh french bread.  Delicious is an inadequate adjective.  

I am also addicted to their steak tar-tare.  It is difficult at best to find this classic in the States and nearly impossible to find it done well.  At L'Express it is exceptional.  I take mine extra spicy.  Served with impeccable frites it is a joy for my palette.  

On our recent visit we enjoyed Il Flotante for dessert.  A light fluffy meringue floating in caramel sauce.  This was the only sub-par item we had. The caramel chunks in the sauce were simply too large and unmanageable.  On previous visits these were broken into small pieces.  This was a small oversight but one the chef should address.

Service here is always impeccable albeit very formal and a bit stuffy.  In part this is because this is definitely a "see and be seen" establishment.  We dined next to a local news anchor although I must admit I didn't know who he was or what all the fuss was about.  

All told this is a fantastic restaurant.  If you're going to Montreal do not miss the opportunity to have classic French Bistro food done well.  You will not be disappointed.

Came here with my lady for a nice evening.  Ordered a bottle of wine and sat down at the bar, since the restaurant was so crowded.  I'm glad we did, because it allowed us to have a more casual dining experience and make friend with the nice older gentleman bartender.

I ordered the pot-au-feu and couldn't have been happier.  It comes with a bit of bone marrow which was delicious and just the right texture.  The veggies and meats were also perfectly done.  Overall, a really nice french experience.

Typical Bistro.  Food was ok.  We had steak frites, fish soup and quail on wild rice.  I actually preferred the wild rice to be more savory, so it doesn't remind me of the Asian (Thai/ Chinese) glutinous rice pudding.

Service was great and ambience is good.

Great food, everything was amazing. With every meal they serve a jar of pickles and Dijon! And though it might be a wee bit on the expensive side, it's worth it.The people  are really friendly there, know their wine and recommended a great one with the meal.   

The only trouble is that the restaurant is too pricey to be a regular restaurant and yet not expensive to be a high end restaurant. As such, there were a few faux pas, I was served first (both wine and food) and had to pour my own glass several times.  This, along with the cheap paper covering the table just made me confused. Nothing to ruin it, just a few small things.

Absolutely fantastic. Extremely good pricing for the quality of the food. We started with the (in season) asparagus, the rillette and the bone marrow (a must try!!). Our waiter was attentive and recommended the perfect wines for our meal. I would return in a heartbeat.

Have been coming here since the 80's.  It has not changed much at all since then.  It is classic and I have never been disappointed.  On this occasion we came for lunch and I had a really lovely shrimp risotto and my other half had the croque monsieur which was prepared in a simple and authentic fashion with awesome frites..

A lot of folks feel this place is maybe not what it used to be.  That has not been my experience at all.  However I would say that times have changed and the overall culinary scene in Montreal has elevated such that there are a lot of great choices and L'Express does not stand out the way it once did.  It does, however, remain on our short list of Montreal dining venues.

I think this place will be a consistent favorite.  It is expensive, but worth it.  I think you have to try it for yourself to believe.

Had the bone marrow, which is great, and a cod appetizer off their specials, which was okay.  Steak for entree was wonderful, husband got the scallops off the specials, which were great as well.  Our server was excellent, full of information and suggestions.  

Dessert was the tarte tatin -- warm with ice cream -- yum.  I had the dark chocolate torte, which is intense but also very flavorful.

I really like the atmosphere, the bar when you walk in, the cute bistro-type tables and chairs, and the way people are crammed in there gives it a cozy feeling.

The people next to us had their small child (5 yrs), and he looked both bored with his food and the location -- not sure if it is a good place for children.  It can also be tight on space for strollers, but I think they are accomodating.

Breakfast at l'Express 

I have tried locating breakfast reviews for l'Express but people seem only to be dining here for dinner. I can say only one thing: you are missing out!

Well, judging by the reviews, I'm the one missing out as I've never stayed for dinner, but I can say with certainty their breakfast is delicious and affordable. Although we're big fans of l'Avenue, Express offers a much different experience and price point. Their coffee is simply the best I've ever had in a restaurant. So much so that it can be enjoyed without milk or sugar (something I have never been able to appreciate with other coffee, with the exception of vacationing in Costa Rica). 

So the highlight has to be their French Toast (Pain Brioché Doré avec syrop d'érable). You're served two thick slices of brioche bread (think challah) cut in four, cooked to perfection: golden and soft on the outside, moist and warm on the inside. Real maple syrup is served, which is a must in Québec. My boyfriend always gets the three oeufs tournés with baguette + bacon and a bowl of divine chocolat chaud. Last time we tried the pear compote, which is a small portion of a wonderfully smooth vanilla-caramel treat: mini spoon provided to indulge! 

We usually go mid-week, so it's never crowded and you feel like you have the place to yourself. Phone starts ringing if you're there close to lunch, but it's all part of the experience. This past time we joined them on a Saturday at 10:30am (they open at 10am on weekends for breakfast) and still were seated right away. The best part is breakfast is served quick so no long waits and bottomless (reg) coffee!

No name shows above the door, just the address 3927 so look for the checkered black & white entrance tiles below the cream-colored exterior and enjoy!

Ahhh... L'Express. It is truly the epitome of a French bistro from the menu, to the design to the ambiance and service. 

It's often deemed a "must visit" while in Montreal and I am inclined to agree. The food has always been stellar, they have a great selection of wines and the pickles and bread at your table are an excellent touch. I regularly order the ravioli and it has been a hit every time.

Definitely a great option for a low-key evening out without pretention, just good food and wine at a fair price.

Decent, typical French restaurant with good service. Their wine menu is extensive.

I wasn't a big fan of the bone marrow many people rave about. I think their menu items can be a hit or a miss, but they have a fair number of options. 

My favourite part was the dessert! They are known for the Floating Caramel Island (the dome-shaped one everyone posts photos of) and it did not disappoint. It was really fun and delicious to eat.

Very charming decor. Good steak frites and grilled salmon, but try elsewhere for tartares and the duck confit. Always great ambience and well tailored clientele. Courteous and professional staff and hilarious bartender.

We used Yelp to find a french restaurant while in town for a few days.  Let me say that without a doubt, it was the best french meal I have had. Like the other reviewers have said, no signs out front (unless you count the sidewalk) so it's a little hard to notice at night (especially in the rain).  The tables are dressed in white linen, but the dress codes varied from jeans and a t shirt on some diners to a suit on others.  Don't forget a reservation!!  The place got to capacity quick!  

Four of us dined together and we had: the lobster risotto, the roasted quail, the duck con fit and the grain-fed chicken in mustard sauce.  They were all simply amazing!  We ended up having to share with each other because of how fantastic everything was.  The salads were perfectly fresh, the vegetables were crisp and the wine list was superb. My best friend and I decided to share a half bottle, and the wait staff was kind enough to split the half-bottle on both of our tabs without us even asking! 

As for the wait staff, they were simply amazing. They were very courteous and even encouraged our poor french, so that we cold try and figure out the menu on our own as they stood by just in case we had questions. But don't worry, they do have English menus!  

The only negative (our fault)  thing I can say is that when you look at the dessert menu, pay close attention. My friend's wife and I ordered the Creme Caramel with orange thinking it would be like a Creme Brulee, but it was more of a thick custard, It was still good, and our own fault for not reading all the way, but just keep that in mind

I cannot wait to go to Montreal again so that we can have a traditional french dining experience at L'express!
it's without a doubt the best french restaurant in montreal

This is by far my favorite restaurant in Montreal. It's retro, it's delicious and it doesn't give a crap if you like it or not (so much so that they dont even have signage. It's like saying "maybe you'll find us, maybe you won't- that's YOUR problem"). The food is elegant, sometimes simple and always delicious. The fish soup is a must, as well as the terrine de foie gras. I love the shrimp risotto, always perfect, always delectable. The waiters can be slightly snobbish and sometimes seem exasperated should you ask a question- but who cares! It adds to the French allure. The important thing is the efficiency and professionalism of these career waiters. This is the place I drag my friends for all major occasions; birthdays, holidays, celebrations, because it's Tuesday (girl's got to eat!). Word to the wise, reserve way in advance for groups of 5+ and don't be surprised if they stick you after 10pm.

Thank you for taking the time to read my review.  I had great expectations for the restaurant, food , staff and ambience.  Unfortunately, none of the above delivered.  The best was the expensive bottle  of Bordeaux that I ordered and had to pour for myself.  Stay away from the Crostini with the goat cheese salad, you need to have a direct line to your Dentist so that your teeth can be fixed after eating in this restaurant.  Govern yourself accordingly.

Do not look for the staff to ask you how your meal is, it doesn't happen.
Fantastic lunch!  The pate, steak tartare and quail were delicious.  Service was also perfect.

Made a reservation an hour before we went (probably got in because it was a Sunday night in July) and then sat down to a wonderful meal! Read the reviews before going and I count myself as one of the new advocates! If you love French Bistro & are a foodie, you'll love L'Express!
Heavenly foi de gras. Veal liver with mashed potatoes. Steak with French Fries. Red wine from Southern France.  Now I have to walk to the hotel to burn some calories.  Worth it.

so.amazing.  Our big night out was between here, and au pied.  I wanted to go somewhere a bit less, well known if you will, so chose L'Express.
The wine list, first of all, is bomb.  If I hadn't already been drinking previously, I would have had a glass of everything on that list.  Super A plus!!
The food was simple, but was an amazing experience.  We had the boiled egg, which was finished with a house made curry "mayo".  The mayo was rich, fragrant and decadent while the eggs cooked to perfection.  It was such a nice combination with the creaminess of the egg.  We also had the goat cheese salad, which consisted of layers of tangy cool goat cheese on toasted amazingness.  Heaven.  
Our entrées were equally delectable.  At the end, our bill was under $80. Can't do that everywhere!
Service was what you get in the old QC, but our back server (busser?) was super, super friendly and knowledgeable, and definitely highlighted the night.
I would totally come back, again and again.

L'Express

After all the reviews I'd read about this bistro, I was tre excited to try it out. The atmosphere was so lively and French! We were immediately seated because of my reservation, and our table was perfect.

We started with the foie gras, which was purely delicious. Then both of us ordered the raviolis. OMG, to die for! The sauce alone was worth scraping the bowl with bread, and the tender meat filling in the ravioli was bliss!

We ended the meal with the apple tarte a la mode.......perfect, perfect, perfect.

The service was slow, but friendly and thorough, so we loved our l-oooong meal. Do yourself a favor and go!

The best meal I have ever had in my entire life! It was so delicious! My boyfriend and I both had steak frites (which it says Hanger Steak on the menu). Neither my boyfriend or I can speak French and the servers were very helpful/accommodating. They give you a jar of pickles and bread while you are waiting for your meal, which came out very quickly! The steak was very tender and flavorful - nothing like I've ever tasted! Give it a try you won't regret it!

You might want to make a reservation beforehand. We went in on a saturday night, and we had to sit at the bar. It wasn't the most comfortable, but it was worth the food!

Excellent! Excellent!

We went there for early lunch. Made a reservation the night before, but we got there late because we had to drive 2 hours from Ottawa to this place.
Even though we were way late for the reserved spot, the host quickly sat us down at the bar. He even apologized that he couldn't sit us at a table. So curtious! 
Pickles were excellent - I don't eat pickles, but I ended up eating at least 10 of their sweet/bit of sourness cute little pickles. 

We ordered bone marrow and Quail on wild rice. Presentation was very nice and both dishes were very rich in flavor. I loved the quail A LOT! 
It was very tender and juicy and yet the skin was caramelized and sweet. The bone marrow was interesting, but definitely too "rich" (greasy taste) for me. 

I also thought the prices were quite fair. The quail was about CAD 18.
In LA, I'm sure that'd be USD 25-30 at least. 

We stolled a bit on St-Denis. Very nice street with lots of unique shops. Highly recommend this restaurant!! 2 thumbs up!!

Great place for breakfast: simple food done just right, fantastic coffee and lovely atmosphere. The morning prices would fall in the $$ category rather than the $$$. Service was very nice, although the food came out very delayed (our waitress did come to us and apologized for the wait).
Great food!!! Came from Toronto, and came here after reading all the reviews and all I can say is ...WOW

Tasty, traditional French fare. Our main complaint was that we wanted more - the duck confit needed some carbs and the quail would have been even more appreciated sitting on a twice-as-high pile of wild rice.

The food was not exactly perfect, but satisfying enough, and the ambiance was great.

Although the atmosphere and service were very nice, the food was truly awful. We ordered the fish soup which was bland, the bone marrow which had a disgusting texture, the calf liver and the toulouse.  The calf liver was not cooked properly, the toulouse tasted like something you would get from a package in the grocery store, and the mashed potatoes were dry like they were from a package.

This place was not worth it at all. It was an awful, overpriced experience and I would not recommend anyone go there. I had a reservation to Maison Publique that night and I wish I had gone there instead. Or Burger King. Both would have been better.

I've been coming here for almost 20 years. It's my favourite restaurant!  Classic French bistro with great food. For a starter I recommend the chèvre chaud or the chicken liver pâté. For a main I get either the steak tartare or the hanger steak. Good drinks and wine list as well. Don't skip a chance to come here!

We went for desserts and drinks and very happy we did.  Desserts were excellent and they had a fairly robust wine list for such a small place.  I ordered a 2011 Bordeaux from the Medoc region that was wonderful.  We will definitely be back.

A bartender down the street recommended L'express for dinner -I did not have high expectations.  Was pleasantly surprised.  Greeted by an unhappy maitre de because we did not have reservations but we did get a table.  This place is so popular that people reserve bar seats.
Great wine selection .  Of course the menu is in french but thankfully they include translation.  They present a canning jar of pickled tiny cucumbers that were very good.  We had the fish soup and shrimp risotto both were great.  Service was impeccable.  
Will definitely make a reservation next time we are in town .

Feels like Paris! Had escargot that was prepared out of the shell on top of potatoe purée. The octopus with lentils was a creative combination. The hangar steak was on the chewy side. We asked for medium, but it was well done. The frit was amazing! Not like any other I have had! The bistro is a gem.

Maybe the best food I have ever had. The duck confit is amazing, so is the frois gras. If you are looking for delicious French Canadian food in Montreal, this is the place to go. It is not cheap, but the price is worth it.

After reading various reviews here we thought we'd give this place a shot.  The food was pretty good.  Warm goat cheese sandwich and a pâté serving big enough to give anybody a heart attack were the starters.  Nice bottle of wine, sea bass and home made raviolis rounded out the meal.  We were happy. 

What we weren't so happy about was the service.  Clearly something went wrong with our service as even the bus boy was coming by to apologize for the wait.  Between the appetizers and the main course it must have been about 40 minutes.  When we walked in with no reservations at about 7:45 the maître d' told us there was a table in the front that was free until 9:00.  Ordinarily we eat pretty quickly so we figured with over an hour to go we wouldn't have any problem.  With the huge delay between servings we got out of there just in the nick of time.  

Regardless of what happened in the kitchen, the wait staff was pleasant and attentive, the food was good, if pricey.

This is my first time to taste risotto. Shrimp risotto is devious. Another serving is Bone marrow with coarse salt. My husband likes very much. The first taste is very good, but after I eat much, I feel a little greasy.

This place is excellent!  The service was great!
The duck confit is absolutely amazing.
Beets salad is delicious. 
Shrimp Risotto is creamy and perfectly seasoned. 
Loved the little pickle. 
I would of been a 5 stars - I took 1 out due to dessert was just so so.  
Perhaps I will try other dessert selection next time. 
Overall.  I am in love with this place.

Amazing meal. From the service, to the wine, to the food itself.

I highly recommend the foie gras and bone marrow to start. 

All the entrees we ordered were impeccable - ravioli, steak frites, chicken and lamb.
Paris à Montréal. Toujours bon et frais. Serveurs professionnels. Bravo!

A staple of Montreal,  my 10th time here probably.  Service is always old school excellent with knowledgeable and experienced servers. Paired with excellent bread and gherkins .. you order a bottle of wine and you are guaranteed a great next 2 hours.  Apps and mains are designed well. Traditional paired with special menu items that surprises. Desserts will please if you aren't too full already from the app and dessert. Just depends on what you order. Drinks menu is large and very reasonable prices. Again.. a staple of montreal
this is french food, the worst I ever had.  no way this is a 4 stars!

Decided to go to L'Express today for lunch after wanting to try this place for sometime. The staff were lovely and the restaurant had a really welcoming feel to it. The food was delicious although nothing 'out of this world'. Coffee was nice and I loved the tartelette citron! Dessert was certainly my favourite part.

Terrible experience in here. There is a waitress did a terrible job to us. Because she wanted to leave work and back home early, she made our order almost all wrong. Really really disrespect to her job.

The veal kidney I ordered didn't taste salted at all--but aside from that, everything was delicious. Service was great as well. I'm a sucker for any place that has exceptional bread and butter, and I almost screamed with happiness when they brought a huge jar of cornichons to the table.

Fancy and locally famous, but a bit overpriced and unmemorable for the quality. The neighborhood, Le Plateau, is similarly overrated. I ate here with my girlfriend and it was among our most expensive meals during a week-long visit to Montréal, but all we really remember were the cornichons and mustard served at the table--the rest was fine, conservative French cooking that disappears from memory sooner than it disappears from your credit card bill.

After Au Pied de Cochon, dinner at L'Express was the best meal I had during my trip to Montreal.  We managed to squeeze in here without a reservation on a Thursday evening. We were seated in a space near the back with an atrium ceiling and tables that were a tad bit close together. The waiter was very friendly and patient with our order, providing plenty of recommendations.

Foodnalysis:
- Bone Marrow - Amazing! A first for my husband and me. The jelly-like consistency and mushy texture is definitely an acquired taste, but if you enjoy trying new things, don't miss this. Excellent presentation, each portion served in the bone with the traditional toasted bread and sea salt.  Fantastic flavor.
- Steak Frites - Wonderful, classic dish.  Can't go wrong with this.
- Steak Tartare - Really, really loved this. If you enjoy tartare of any sort, do give this a try. The meat was flavored with just the right amount of lemon juice to enhance the natural juices.  

The Bottom Line:
Highly recommended French bistro.  Try the bone marrow and the steak tartare (if you're into raw!) or steak frites.
Amazing Bistro! Great for soloing at the bar too. perfect menu selection. Great wine list. Will be back!

Excellente brasserie. Tout le charme d'une brasserie parisienne au coeur de Montréal.
Service impeccables, un beau comptoir, des plats succulents et traditionnels. Je recommande d'essayer le pot aux feu, et les os à moelle.

I initially came across L'Express in United Airlines' Hemispheres magazine, which included the restaurant in its Three Perfect Days in Montreal article. When I saw how well reviewed L'Express was on Yelp, I put it on our "must" list, and am so glad I did. We had a lovely lunch there during a weekend getaway to Montreal.

The restaurant itself looks straight out of a Parisian brasserie, much to my boyfriend's (a Francophile if ever there was one) delight. The bar is mahogany, the floor is done in black and white tile, and the tables are covered with white tablecloths and paper - just as one would expect to find. We sat at the back of the restaurant where we had a good look at black and white photographs depicting the restaurant and its staff for every year L'Express has been in business, and were quite impressed to see how many employees have remained at the restaurant for 5+ years.

Service is slow, but one should expect that - the French do not rush through their meals the way Americans do (which means yes, there should be significant pauses in between courses, and yes, you should have plenty of time to review the menu before being asked to make selections). If you want the waiter, signal - he's not going to hover over your table and pressure you to leave the minute you've finished your plate, thank goodness. 

We did not have a reservation but should have made one - this restaurant is very busy, and if you don't want to wait, I would recommend planning ahead.

When it comes to food, I thought L'Express held their own. I started with the courgette soup, which was creamier than I prefer, and I detected what seemed to be bacon crumbles on top, which I could have done without. That being said, it was a delicious soup, and I was more than happy to polish it off with some wonderful fresh bread. My main course, the quail, was absolutely divine. It was accompanied by a beautiful balsamic vinegar over a bed of wild rice. My boyfriend and I shared the tarte au chocolat for dessert, and while it was quite rich, we really enjoyed it.

Quite frankly, I found the L'Express experience to be quite pleasant - it was certainly the most memorable lunch I had in Montreal this October.

Authentic french food that is fresh and light. I had the sea bass and my date had the quail.  The preparation for both dishes was very simple, but allowed the freshness of the ingredients used to shine through. My only complaint is that the sea bass had too much olive oil on the fish and the vegetable side. We sat at the bar and our server/bartender was entertaining and helpful.  There Is no sign on the outside so this place Is easy to miss!

ATMOSPHERE

Walking in to the restaurant, it felt like I was transported to Paris. Yes, I can say this. I've been. The checkered floors and bar really brought me back. Not that I was by any means drinking as a 15 year old in France. Although I probably could have. The menu reflected adherence to classic French cuisine.

FOOD

I had the Sautéed Duck Confit Salad || Duck sits atop spinach, radishes, croutons and green bean. I loved the different take on duck confit and the fact that it was such a light meal. 

OVERALL

All in all, I was so full from breakfast and lunch meals. I wish I had had the room for dessert. I will certainly come back to try some! The atmosphere and food really made for a great meal.

By far the best service during my visit in Montreal. The food was also very good 

To start we had the mushroom truffle dish which basically has the same sauce as the mushroom ravioli, so pick one or the other. otherwise, it gets old pretty quick :/

we also had the duck salad thing which was quite tasty. would have preferred slightly more greens, but there was plenty of meat which was well seasoned.

we also had the vegetable garden soup which was just ok. probably wouldnt order again

the bread kept coming and the service was a solid 5*

would definitely come back to try other dishes. ie the risotto, which looked quite yum

We came here based on the great yelp reviews. It was a bit disappointing since we were expecting much better based on all the positive reviews. We ordered a mushroom tart, steak/fries, and ravioli. Everything was cooked properly, but the taste was just average. The only thing I would recommend is steak, and fries.
tourist stay away from this place: over price, average food, service mediocre, over rated. don"t let the over rating fool you. horrible place.

Incredible authentic French in Montreal. No trip to the North American Canadian City is complete without a true French meal. 

The ambiance is a classic no frills steakhouse - clean white table cloths and pictures of the restaurant team over the years on the wall. The meal begins with an incredible fresh baguette and the cutest tiniest pickles I've ever seen. I got the steak frites and my friends also got the beef tartare and salmon. All were incredible, and the pepper crusting on the steak was to die for. 

We also had a refreshing rose, and finished off with delicious cappuccinos. Great meal and would definitely recommend for anyone looking for French flavors!

Everything food is simply perfect - from the tartar to the bone marrow to the fish to the pasta - and the quality of wine for the price is insane value. Every bottle on the menu, including those that cost $25-35 is first class for what it is. Service is on point. Pound for pound one of MTL's best.

We came from California did not make reservation.
The hostess was very nice gave us the table.
Food and services were excellent. We could not try the Floating Island or Creme Brûlée because they both sold out. Will definitive come back soon.

One of the best restaurants I've been to and probably the best of the many upscale restaurants we tried in Montreal. 

Duck confit - excellent.

Pickles - outstanding.

Mustard - great.

Steak tartare - good but not the best I've had.

Service - good.

I would come back here in a heartbeat if I make it back to Montreal.

Classic French cuisine. Welcoming atmosphere. Casual and unpretentious. Broad selection of wine by the glass. Extremely knowledgeable bar men who can steer you towards optimal wine/food pairings and will respect if you are on a budget. Absolutely a worthwhile spot if you like French food and wine in a traditional but still lively ambiance.

Montrealers are spoiled in the sense that good food can be reasonable. Here is a place that is so good that the folks in the resto industry eat at. Tiles on the floor and a just a great atmosphere. The Dore Almondine is excellent. Just a fantastic brasserie.

Excellent! Food was amazing .. Staff attentive.  I had the Halibut special with fiddleheads and my husband the veal with morels ... Finished up with the l'isle de caramel for dessert  everything was perfectly prepared! c'est manefic!

From the US perspective I think there's a lot of hype surrounding L'express because it was written on a couple of short-lists of must-eats in MTL - probably most notably in NYT.  Pre publicity it seemed like a great place to know to eat, a wonderful bistro with all the trim - indulge in anything, enjoy a cigarette between courses and lose your concerns in a great meal.  Indulge in everything but self consciousness.
The food is very good - reliable and delicious over years. 
Authenticity may wane with acclaim here...

Toujours agréable, le matin après 8H00 ou tard en soirée. Le meilleur Bistro français de Montréal qui trône sur la rue St-Denis depuis plus de deux décennies. Ma préférence va au potage à l'oseille si vous aimez l'amertume, unique à Montréal. Les pâtes serves avec fond de veau et champignons, si vous aimés le beurre! Le service est toujours impeccables. Les hôtes on généralement un sens aiguë de la repartie ce qui ajoute un brin de folie à la joute culinaire. Encore faut-il savoir jouer! On adore!

L'express is the quintessential perfect French bistro in Montreal.

We had reservations for 6:30pm on a Saturday, but were easily able to switch it to a 9:30pm ressie. When we arrived, the place was bustling and there were a good number of people waiting to be seated. Our table took a little while to be ready for us, but we only waited 10 mins max.

Along the walls are a ton of photos dating back to the 1970s, when L'express began. If a business has made it this far, it's good in my book. 

We ordered 2 half bottles of 2007 Bordeaux ($16 each), and started off with Bone Marrow and Foie Gras apps. We then ordered the duck confit salad, hanger steak frites, sea bass, and quail for our mains. 

The foie gras was nommalicious - I am a foie gras FIEND. MORE MORE MORE! It also came with a bucket of pickles that my friend could not stop eating (Hi Anita! :P) The bone marrow was pretty good too, but I have had better in NYC. The hanger steak was on par with normal steak frites. The duck confit was de-skinned and de-boned, which was disappointing because I was looking forward to that crunchy duck skin - but the meat was extremely flavorful. The sea bass was melt in yo'mouth. And this leaves the quail... OMG the QUAIL! So freaking good. Please do yourself a favor and get it. Amazeballs.

Such a huge fan of L'express! Perfect service, great food.

L'Express is one of the iconic French restaurants in Montreal dating back to the 80's. The restaurant's interior is classy, and for the short period of time that you're there the clock gets turned back. My friends and I ordered several things to share:

Celery remoulade: thin strips of celery root tossed in a housemade remoulade sauce topped with chives. This was quite large in portion, and the remoulade sauce was very strong. A bit too tart for my taste, but served as a nice appetizer.

Roasted quail with wild rice: this was delicious. The quail was perfectly roasted with a slightly crispy exterior. The meat was moist and very flavorful, and the wild rice and quail eggs both served as nice sides.

Epaule de porcelet croustillante: roughly, this is crispy pork loin in a creamy mustard sauce. But it's not just any pork: porcelet is a pig suckling that is fed with milk, and is truly the "cream of the crop" when it comes to pork. Unfortunately I am not a pork eater, but my friend did say that this was some of the best pork that he has ever had.

Ttoro basque: a Basque style fish stew cooked with pieces of sea bass, shrimp, mussels, fennel, and potatoes in a rich fish broth. This was perhaps one of the best fish stews that I have ever had. The fish broth was strong but not overpowering, and had a nice sweetness in the taste. All of the seafood weren't overcooked, and the roasted fennel really compliment the entire stew very nicely. Literally wiped the entire bowl clean (I had to ask for extra bread!).

Orange creme caramel: for dessert, we shared this, which is essentially a flan topped with candied orange peel in a caramel sauce. Simple, but elegantly presented. The orange peels were delicious and not even slightly bitter, and complimented the slightly sweet flan and caramel sauce well. A delicious ending.

Service was very good, and our server was patient explaining to us virtually everything on the menu as we indecisively made our orders. Kudos to them!

This stands as one of the most memorable meals that I have had in quite some time. A real bummer that I can't be coming here everyday!

A Montréal institution with true Parisien flair, value, professional staff, impeccable wine list, a "must" in this city.
Although open for lunch and dinner (going into the wee hours) I enjoy breakfast at this resto

Where am I?  Am I in Strausberg?
And did that Garson really just slap himself for spilling wine?

Will frequent...from Boston.

Everything about our meal here was pretty spot on. The food was amazing, and the price at the end was extremely reasonable. 

Standouts for me
chicken liver with pistachio - I'm not normally a big fan of pate, but this was addicting. I couldn't stop eating it I loved it.
octopus/lentil salad - octopus was cooked perfectly, salad was presented beautifully.
beef tartare - wouldn't normally think of getting tartare as an entree but I wanted so much of this that it makes sense. amazing

the rest of the dishes were also great - bone marrow, steak frites, roasted quail, seabass, pork and mushroom raviolis

we also ordered a couple desserts, which everyone said were amazing - I was stuffed from the meal that I couldn't fit another bite

First, it's on St. Denis street, who clearly was the BEST of all the Saints.  So they get 5 stars for location. 

Came here for an early dinner, around 6:30.  No problem getting in.   By 7:30 it was packed, so make sure to make reservations! 

The service was more efficient than polite.  Nothing to make you feel unwanted, but nothing to give you that friendly feeling either.  However, it was very quick and prompt.  It could have been because our table was reserved for 8:15 (which they told us twice) and they wanted to get rid of us quick, but the service was very fast.  Which is a huge plus. 

The complimentary bread was absolutely delicious.  Not warm, but super fresh.  I got the steak and fries, which I now realize is my usual order at a french place.  The steak was pretty good, the fries were golden and crispy, really good.  For dessert I got a lemon tart (though it was called something else in french).  Not the regular watered down taste, super lemony, so I was a huge fan! 

The ambiance is nothing special, especially for the price.  Everything is plain, nothing is particularly clean, though it's not dirty either.  The tables have white papers on them...  At first glance it could be a deli with a bar.

**3.5**

After much hype about this restaurant I made a reservation for Friday night. It was the first restaurant we went to on our weekend trip to Montreal. The restaurant by itself has a nice vibe to it, its a lively setting. We were seated immediately and started to place or orders. We had the bone marrow and foie gras for starters. I have to agree with one other reviewer when I say the quantity of the bone marrow was a lot, there were four of us at the table and we still had a tough time finishing it. Its a very rich dish and having too much of it killed the joy for me. It was my first time trying foie gras and I have to admit I did not like it, hence I can't really comment upon it. I had read about different styles in which it could be made and maybe I would have liked that more versus it being served just as is...

Moving on the the main course, Mr. H had the chicken and said it was good, another friend had the risotto and loved it, one friend had the steak frites and had more to say regarding the frites vs. the steak. I had the quail and it was absolutely amazing! I dropped my fork and nibbled on it with my hands, out went the etiquette!

For dessert we had the chocolate tart and it was fine. Overall the experience was a lot of ups and downs, for the price we paid it should have been awesome. I left a little disappointed and maybe next time I'll try another place.

- The quail and the risotto were the highlights!

I'll start the review by saying I enjoyed the food and the star review doesn't reflect that. 

But... There were live ants in one of our bread trays! We didn't make a fuss, because I think we all weren't the type, but we did call the waiter over and pointed it out and asked him to remove that tray of bread. We also stayed and ordered partly because we were in shock, and partly because we don't like fusses and it would be strange to walk out of the restaurant. And partly because we were hungry (it's hard to make rational decisions when hungry and near food) and figured it was probably a one time deal (it was. We checked all the rest of the bread bowls and no ants). 

The waiter took away the bread bowl quickly... And the situation wasn't brought up again. We got our food. It was pretty tasty.
