- Next time I want to try out the veal livers, quiche and the pot au feu 

Other:
- Prices are a little high but for the quality of the food, it's a great deal 
- Great vibe and a special place
- Recommend sitting at the bar
Amazing, authentic French cuisine and great service! Loved the food and ambiance and energy!  Courteous service!

I love this restaurant! It is the closest thing to an authentic Parisian restaurant. I love their black and white checkered floor. Their food is very good too. When you first sit down, they bring you a jar of gherkins and a sliced baguette - so good, it is addictive :) 
My favourite meal at this restaurant is definitely their Ravioli. 
Another great thing to now is that they are open for Late Night menu. You won't be stuck having a bad meal even at midnight!
My only draw back is in my personal opinion, there is a je-ne-sais-quoi missing from this restaurant in terms of ambiance. Otherwise, excellent!

Went there fore lunch on a beautifully sunny day. First thing you notice walking in is the trademark black & white square tiles. Feels very French-bistro-y (for lack of better descriptive).

I was less than impressed with the food for the prices. Presentation was lacking, although quality was there. My favourite was the duck confit salad by far. Bone marrow was too much for one person, there were barely any escargots in my escargot dishes (would have been better renamed to escargot flavoured sauce), and the ravioli portion was too small... Otherwise, the octopus was amazing, lentils were okay.

Definitely try if you have time (and the money), some people love it and find it very authentic. For me, it just didn't do it.

Devoured
Escargots en sauce
Os à moelle - gros sel 14.00$
Truffe maison 1.30$
Champagne 40.00$
Pieuvre et lentilles - vinaigrette 17.15$
Raviolis maison 20.50$
Sauté de canard confit avec salade 24.90$

Came here recently as it was on my list of places to try when visiting Montreal. Called day of on Saturday and was able to get a table for 2 at 645pm.

We got served the complimentary bread and butter. Butter was cold, which made it terrible for spreading. I'm not sure why some restaurants don't provide room temp or whipped butter as it just comes off as cheap otherwise. 

We ordered the bone marrow, ravioli and hanger steak. The bone marrow was as expected and not bad. The ravioli was decent and had a interesting mushroom sauce. The steak was cooked well however the fries seemed fairly oily (puddle of oily at the bottom). 

Overall, I think the prices are above average for what you get and the experience is average at best. I feel like this is one of those restaurants that's been around a long time and is surviving due to its history vs the actual food quality.

Classic French bistro as fine, as wonderful as any found in Paris- don't miss the experience, the ambience, the food. The soups themselves are perfection- 
Put this one on your Montreal list- Ben Harper does.

I've been to this resto many years ago when I lived in Montreal so I decided to take my family for a French bistro dinner while I was in town. Since foie gras is banned in SF, we decided to get the foie gras terrine for $31 and thought it would be huge portion, it definitely wasn't $31 worth of foie gras. Aren't the foie from Quebec?! The oysters were teeny tiny, sea bass was very tender, beef tartare was just so-so, kidneys were tasty and duck steak was probably the best dish. The ambiance was loud and had a great french bistro feel, so overall pretty good food but overpriced for what you're getting. Unfortunately, don't think I'll be going back.

Always worth a visit when in Montreal. Can be crowded and you might have to wait if no reservation but the food is authentic and the vibe is
good.
Stay with the traditional French dishes and enjoy yourself.
Alan/ New York

Seriously excellent, I sat solo at the bar which was lovely. Enjoyed the quail w/ asparagus. Atmosphere is medium loud, was packed with a good looking crowd. Fantastic waiters.....jars of cornichons w/ bread for each table.....so awesome!

Came here for Valentine's Day. This is the second time I've  been to L'express. The bone marrow portion was extremely generous and the presentation of the octopus salad was an instagrammers dream. We ordered the calf liver and steak tartare. The calf liver was some of the best I've ever had and was cooked perfectly. We finished with  a chocolate tart and creme brule. The tart was decadent but not overpoweringly sweet. Great place for authentic french cuisine in Montreal.
Try the pork/veal ravioli, made with shallots. You will get a lot of bread.

This charming French bistro is right out of Paris, and the real Balthazar experience. Upon entering, one senses that they have entered a special and iconic place. Traveling alone, I made a reservation for the bar. I assumed that I would just be placed at the bar when there was an opening. I was wrong. I arrived to find a table setting for me, a place mat and a card saying "reserved" at the space designated for me at the bar. It was a special way to begin the meal. The bartenders and waiters were exactly what I would expect at a French restaurant, and very attentive. 

The soup came in a beautiful bowl and accompanied by cheese bread slices. I chose the steak frites for my entree. The meat was succulent, juicy and able to be cut with a fork. The fries were crunchy, salty and perfection. I normally don't order hanger steak and fries, but I'm so happy that I did. It's the best I've ever had or could hope to have again.

The wine list too is substantial and reasonable options exist. 

The prices are incredibly reasonable for such a nice experience, with most entrees in the $15 to $25 range.

We had a reservation for 8:30 and the gentleman actually was able to take us early.  I am giving a 5 star review for the service and the spaghetti and mushroom. Yum!! The bread was cold but decent and my husbands got the steak and fries. Nothing special. That's where I had to drop it a star. Definitely a place to go to if you get the right thing. Very professional staff too.

Always a five star meal... year after year... had bone marrow, chicken pate, hanger steak, veal kidney, cheese tonight.  Everything was good as always but star of the night was the veal kidney!  It's not even a dish you see on menu in French restaurants in Ny... probably because either they can't source the ingredient or chef doesn't know how to prepare it right... here, not an issue!  

Compared to last night's dinner which was very good too, but the fact that I'm just as happy (and secretly a little happier tonight)... L'express is really a relatively bargain (halve the price of last night's dinner to be exact)

This won in spades. Sophisticated bistro . Varied. Very intelligent wine/aperatif  list. Stellar dine at the bar service Fine fish soup 
with excellent alioli + croutons. Rognons a la  moutard approximate my own moose version. Tartare highly satisfactory ( still, read Robichon ) frites sucked - but so do they in most Parisian bistros these days,41/2 stars.

Went here last night and had a great meal and overall experience. Their goat cheese salad is amazing, and everything we ordered was good (croque monsieur, the kidney, country style soup, and the crumble for dessert). The waitstaff was extremely attentive without being overwhelming, and very kind despite the fact that we were a bit underdressed and slightly out of place (re: You'll feel better in a collared shirt and don't wear jeans). Best meal I've had in a long time and by far the best I've had in Montreal!

My friends and I went for lunch at 1pm without reservation. The maitre d was efficient and sat us quickly. It was clean overall, narrow, and noisy from the end of the lunch crowd. Two of us ordered roasted quail with wild rice, one had duck confit with salad, and chicken. Don't order the iced tea for 4.50 each. There was no refills.The food was excellent but the service was slow and abrupt at times. Ginette warmed up with us after we complimented her on the photos we looked on the walls. The annual staff photos were framed and hung on the walls leading to the bathrooms. If you are not used to French attitudes, you might think they are a tad bit snooty. Otherwise, food is excellente and oh la la. Good job! Keep up with the quality of the food service!

The brunch here is FABULOUS!

I came here for breakfast with a friend who's a local on a weekend trip to Montreal, and I felt like I was whisked across the pond and in Paris.  The ambiance was classy and casual.  Very clean and chic.  The aesthetics were like a Parisienne cafe in the 1920's.  The food was delicious and perfectly portioned.  We left feeling full and content, but not 'stuffed' or bloated.

I ordered eggs and a baguette and my friend ordered a quiche.  I ordered a cappuccino and he ordered an expresso.  Everything was delish!  I also found that the menu was very reasonably priced, and I would vote this restaurant as 2 $$ and not 3 $$$, as currently listed on Yelp.

Our servers were so friendly and knowledgeable of the menu.  It was clear they were very proud of the food they served and happy to help us.  I'm an American and an Anglophone, but I felt very respected here, and the servers even made attempts to speak with me in English.  I spoke to them exclusively in French, but I appreciated their understanding and incredible hospitality.  It made dining here a memorable experience.  I would love to go back.

Very good French restaurant, definitely improved over the last few years.
We got the beef tartar and home made ravioli. Both were amazing. The ravioli was thick and flavourful whereas the tartar was super fresh and well seasoned as well. You must order a wine to elevate the flavours?
The service was slow though.

I loved this place.  Its in a great neighborhood that we didn't get a chance to really explore.  I got a Greenwich Village vibe from it.  The service started a little snotty but then became really helpful and friendly.  I loved the art deco ambiance inside.
As someone from Chicago I'm used to restaurants, especially on a Sunday, to shut down by 11 pm.  Not this one!  We left well past 11 and they were still seating people for dinner!  
I think I may have filled up on pickles and bread though.. both are very good (esp the butter)
We started with the octopus and lentil salad which was maybe the best dish of the whole weekend.  Top 3 at least.  I had the shrimp risotto and it had a wonderful flavor.  The rice may have been a little over done/mushy but the shrimps and the sauce made up for that!  My friend go the steak and said it was just ok.  I think the meat was a little tough.  
Then we received some dessert wine from the house as a thank you for moving our table so they could accommodate a big party.  We had their signature floating meringue with it.  OMG it was like nothing I've ever had!  Really good but I was really full!  
I think the best part of this restaurant is the people watching.  It was like Mulberry Street!  I'd be back if I'm ever in Montreal again.

Tout est parfait: le service, la cuisine, la déco. C'est un classique et pas pour rien. Belle sélection de vins au verre. Mes plats préférés: os à la moelle, mousse de foie de volaille, ravioli, spaghetti aux champignons, onglet de buf et frites. Et comme dessert: tatin aux pommes à la mode.
So good. Roasted Beet salad, roasted quail, reasonably priced bottles of wine, and to die for desserts. Go!

From the huge wooden bar to the black and white checkered floor to the old fashioned wine glasses, this place is so much fun and retro BUT doesn't sacrifice on flavor. It's just great french fare in a throw-back environment that won't cost you an arm and a leg. It's certainly not the best resto in Montreal, but with french bistros costing you a dime a dozen here, this one's by far the most worth it. 

The crowd is fun, the wait staff is quick and friendly, and the steak frites is just as it should be: crispy golden fries next to buttery pan-seared bavette. I also really loved the jar of gherkins and the bowl of dijon they leave on the table. Apparently, this is very french. Other things I've had-- the lamb, the mushroom ravioli- is just good. The presentation was a bit 80s and the portions were small, but both were tasty. L'Express also has baba au rhum for dessert-- but it sells out, so go early! Reservations are a good idea.

Excellent! Not sure if this L'express or the one in Manhattan came first but they are both delightful. I was so glad to be able to get a 7:30 reservation here.  The smoked salmon appetizer with capers and onions was wonderful as well as was the quail and shrimp risotto. The wait staff was extremely attentive but not overbearing which is a hard balance to hit. I was pleased to note that although they are known for their wines that they also had beers on tap. I appreciated that the menu was translated into several languages. I would love to come back here when we return to Montreal
Amazing, amazingly authentic French cuisine and great service! Loved the food and ambience and energy! Bon apetit!

Having never been to exposed to Montreal French dining, I wasn't sure what to expect.  The place looks like a small diner with linoleum floors and for all we knew, our waiter might have been proctoring a algebra quiz while taking our order.  My girlfriend doesn't normally enjoy salad but she sure enjoyed the warm duck salad, so much so she would not stop raving about it.  I don't really crave foie gras but it was tasty and served like a thin slice of butter with toasted sliced baguettes.  

Without realizing it, I had ordered the foie gras appetizer as a main and had to order another main course, or I would have been eating bread and liver for dinner.  Quail over wild rice was my last dish and it was served with a sweet red wine reduction.  For me, it was a learning experience in French food.  

The food wasn't amazing, it was good.  Of note, the bone marrow was ordered by two people at the table next to us and neither person seemed to really enjoy it.  One guy actually voiced his displeasure to the waiter when the check came around saying, "this was not what I expected", so take that for what its worth.
Good atmosphere! If you like tradition style French cuisine, L'express definitely is a good choice!

This is one of my favorite restaurants.  We were in Montreal for the weekend and went to grab some drinks at a local establishment.  While there we asked the bartenders what they thought was the best food in Montreal.  They both agreed that L'express was the spot to go.  So we took our chances and headed over on a Saturday night, no reservations.  Apparently we got super lucky, since most people say you need to book well in advance.  We got a table in 5 minutes and then the unbelievable experience began.

The waiter was so nice and explained everything well.  We got the pate and the steak tartar per the bartenders recommendations.  I absolutely hate pate and have tried several different kinds., However, my husband loves it and he made me try this one.  It was incredible.  I didn't want to stop eating it.  The steak tartar was equally as good.  It was by far the best pate and tartar we've eaten.

For my main dish i got the lobster risotto which was delicious.  By the end of the night we were both thoroughly satisfied and agreed that we completely lucked out by meeting those bartenders (Baldwin Barmacie, check them out for some good cocktails!).  Cannot wait to go back to L'express!

We had been walking up and down St. Denis all afternoon, during a brief vacation in Montreal.  Realizing L'Express was nearby, we stopped by in the early evening on a weekday and were able to get a seat at the bar, without a reservation.  The restaurant was beautifully lit, with a black and white tiled floor.  Since we were a little tired and weren't experiencing the whole sit-down fancy experience, we kept our food orders pretty light, not too rich.

I ordered the delicious steak tartare, dressed with sea salt and capers, with fries and lemony hollandaise on the side. i had been wanting to try steak tartare for the longest time, since it is not a common (or trust-worthy) item to order from even upscale Indiana restaurants.  My dining partner ordered the hangar steak medium-rare and fries (or frites...whatever), and really enjoyed it.  A jar of gherkins was in arms-reach on the bar; a nice touch, especially for us pickle lovers. The bartender was our main service contact; he was pleasant and attentive, without invading our privacy or pressuring us to hurry up (even as the restaurant filled up).  

Overall, I got to try something on my foodie wish list (steak tartare!) and we got to experience L'Express at the last minute, without a reservation...you couldn't wish for more, given our lack of planning.  I think if I got to try out the whole normal sit-down experience, going all out with wine, appetizers, and whatnot, that L'Express would definitely be a 5-star visit.

pot au feu... two bites of leathery beef, a grey tasteless boiled chicken leg, a piece of cabbage, two carrots and bone marrow.  other than the bone marrow, i pretty much make a better dinner than this by opening a can of Cambell's Chunky Soup for 2bucks at home.  this is about the experience of eating a rustic dish, but jeez, that was a joke.  wish i had tried the steak frites.  my friend had the steak tartare which was good, but not miles above any other steak tartare he's had at good restaurants.

We were recommended this place from a work friend. 

The establishment was decent with a vintage vibe. The menu had all the choices you'd expect with a couple of fish options. A couple of chicken and a few off the cuff type like calf liver and veal kidney. 

The wine list was quite vast with a wide range of price points. We chose a 60$ Riesling bottle which was a good tasting wine. But they thought is was acceptable to serve at room temperature expecting us to enjoy a first glass semi warm while we waited for it to chill in the bucket of ice. 

The other issue we had with our experience is with a entrée price of 25$-30$ it was sub par quality. It looked like something that could be made at home with a sloppy presentation. Average flavour. I had the sea bass and my wife the lobster risotto. 

The dessert we asked what they recommended, which was the apple tart. When we dove into it, it seemed like a piece that was left uncovered in the back of fridge for a week or two. The apples were this weird dark jelly on top and then more standard underneath. Flavour nothing special.

I wouldn't recommend this from our experience.

L'Express, for me, is just another restaurant in Montreal that let me down. I'm seriously beginning to question the dining scene up there. L'Express is a proper bistro complete with bare essential service. We also waited 40 minutes beyond our reservation time. Trust me the free beer was not worth waiting 40 minutes. 

The food was only worthy of two stars. Salad was just a salad. Terrine of foie gras was nice but not worth 30 CAD. (Why on every menu in Canada is foie gras so expensive? I find it much for expensive than anywhere I've been the USA.). Veal cheek casserole was nice but nothing special. The risotto could have used more protein in it. Lamb was OK. Just nothing popped out as being above average. However, the bread was awesome. 

No need for me to come back here.

Bless this place for being open late AND for being delicious, as the two rarely go hand in hand. 

Our flight to Montreal had arrived around midnight and we were starving. Luckily I had a whole list of Montreal bistros that I had researched before arriving, and this one was not only just down the street from our hotel but was also listed as being open until 2am. We never would have found it it without the address, since there's no sign other than the lettering on the sidewalk tiles. I thought it might be a problem that we were coming in so late and ordering so much food, but our service was absolutely fantastic. When 2am rolled around, our server told us there was no rush, that in fact only the kitchen closed at 2 but actually they were open until 3am, so we could take our time.  

Now onto the food, which was so good we ended up coming here again a few days later to try some more. We started off with appetizers of bone marrow, chicken liver pâté, and an octopus lentil salad. Not to mention that the table came with a big jar of cornichons and mustard. Everything was great, but I think we all really liked the octopus lentil salad the best. Next up, we had hangar steak w/shallot butter & frites, steak tartare, and a duck confit salad. Again, everything was delicious, and the steak was cooked perfectly. They had a very good wine list, so we had a couple good bottles to go with all of that. Finally, we closed with a plate of local Québec cheeses (one raw blue cowmilk cheese, and one raw sheepsmilk cheese), which we had accompanied by honey and a 1/2 bottle of Jurançon dessert wine, and espresso. We loved our food and the way they took care of us so well. 

We went again for lunch a few days later, and it was extremely crowded, but they managed to find a spot for us although we didn't have reservations. We repeated a few dishes from before, but we also this time tried a goat cheese salad, the rillettes, the roasted quail and the sole doré. My quail was so meaty and tender, and it had a nice honey glaze, and Mike's fish was excellent. For dessert we got their famous île flottante (a big scoop of meringue coated with hardened sugar) and a parfait. Service was once again excellent, impressive considering how busy it was.

Over all, we were very pleased with the food and service coming from such a humble place. I think that's the challenge of French bistro cooking, to do simple food very well, and L'Express manages this marvelously.

LOVED IT!! Really nice, courteous, accommodating staff. We came in on a recommendation from a friend, around 8:30 on Saturday night, without a reservation, and the staff did their best to accommodate us. The food was delicious, the service wonderful, we were thrilled! I should mention that we, as a group, are not easily impressed, we dine out a lot, and are fortunate enough to live in cities that offer fantastic food and restaurants. L'express was the dining highlight of our vacation! Thank you L'express! Keep up the great work!!

I was visiting Montreal and am already planning my next visit so I can return to L'express. I loved the complimentary pickle jar, couldn't stop eating them. For meals between the two of us we had salmon tartare and goat cheese salad for apps, the quail and duck confit for entrees, Sancerre wine and were too full for dessert. Every single thing was incredible. I am not a duck or quail type of girl (swearing the night before I wouldn't try either) and I loved both dishes. Definitely a must visit for some delicious French food.

Visiting Montreal from Boston. Made a reservation at L'Express for Easter Sunday breakfast (11:15am) as they were completely booked for brunch. When we arrived we were promptly seated at a nice table for 2. Shortly thereafter a waiter took our drink order but it took quite sometime for our drinks (mimosa w/champagne $$$$) to be delivered by another server. Then another new server came over to answer our questions (the menu is only in French and we only speak English) and take our order. We were then surprised to hear our first server, the one that took our drink order tell, the table behind us the specials which we were never informed or. Our breakfast came out quickly and was decent (omelette and quiche) but the service was awful. No one ever came back to check on us, so we weren't able to order additional drinks when we wanted to. And we had to flag someone down for the check, well past the time we wanted to leave. Looking around the restaurant it seemed like we were the only ones receiving this horrible service - I assume because we were the only English speaking Americans. I would not recommend this restaurant to anyone visiting Montreal from the US for that reason.
I had a shrimp risotto and my partner had a 'canard sauté'  with salad. It was all excellent

I think I expected just a little bit too much here. In terms of French authenticity, this restaurant has met my expectations. Unfortunately the portions I got lacked considering the price.

The octopus and lentil salad was good, however I wanted more octopus and less lentils. Good thing my friends liked lentils so they finished that instead. The bone marrow was probably one of my favs.

The hanger steak was good, but the tartare steak was a disappointment; it just tasted like just any other steak.

Service was also a hit and miss. It took about 10 minutes for someone to finally come over (and that's after we waved someone over...I know, disrespectful on my end) to take our order.

Again, considering the price we paid, I probably won't go back. I think 3 stars is a bit too generous, only because I do like French cuisines and I can't complain about the environment overall.

We had a hard time finding places to eat in Montreal due to lack of Yelp users there.  We did find this restaurant, though, and it was absolutely fantastic.  Some of the most flavorful food I have ever had.  I wanted to order seconds (I got the ravioli).  It was amazing.

excellent food, great service, authentic french bistro atmosphere and reasonable prices. we had the oysters, fish soup, steak frites, that floating iles dessert and everything was perfect. our server pascale was charming and professional - perfect meal. we will be coming back for sure. merci l'express.
French bistro - classic dishes, nothing nouvelle or molecular, thank god. Excellent celeri remoulade and foie de veau à l'estragon. Service friendly and professional. Cheaper than flying to Paris.

Really enjoyed the atmosphere, especially sitting at the counter rather than at a table. Just wished the food was more enjoyable. Also got the impression that as non-French speakers and as tourists as contrasted with apparent regulars, we were treated in inferior manner by our service person. Too bad given the ambience and history.
Did not meet expecations. Too pricey for the quality you get. Cocktails were watered down, sea bass was over-oiled. Pickles and mustard were the best thing there.

The only reservations that were available on Saturday night were at 10pm and we were lucky to get them. When we left 2+ hours later, people were still being seated for dinner!

A very affordable bistro that is really easy to miss if you are not paying attention as it is not very well signposted.

The foix gras was incredible, the steak frites probably one of the best I've ever had and the creme caramel a l'orange was exquisite. 

Service was friendly and efficient and I even learned that rare is saignant in French.

My friend took me there for the first time 4.5 years ago, and I remember my experience there quite pleasant.  My friend had the foie gras, and it went very well with bread.

4.5 years later, I find myself back at L'Express again, and my 2nd experience remained pleasant.  We didn't have reservations, so we did have to wait 45 minutes to get a table (we walked around rue St. Denis, so no problem).  The decor is reminiscent of an European (presumably French, duh?) bistro:  very brightly lit and simple tables with a giant mirror.  

The food was decent.  I love the little pickles they provide in the jar.  I got the octopus with lentil salad.  The plating was very interesting (octopus packed like a can with the lentils inside), and the salad was tasty.  My friend got the warm goat cheese salad that she said was delicious, and another friend got grilled salmon with spinach which the salmon was big.  We then got 3 desserts that were all very tasty and light to eat:  apple/pear pudding, the orange 'flan,' and a chocolate mousse cake.  My small concern about this place is the service is a little slow and we did have to wait a while to get a table.

So I can say that in that 4.5 years span, L'Express remains consistent with the quality of the food (and unfortunately with the wait as well).

For me, it doesn't get better than this! Classy Parisian style bistro with excellent service and a great atmosphere. 

We were in town for a boys trip; I am glad I had the foresight to make a reservation as it looked like it would be tough to get a table for 4 on a Friday night.

3 of us had the hanger steak + frites while 1 friend went for the sea bass. We were all very happy with our meals - the steak was cooked perfectly and the shallot butter was a tasty addition to the dish. They have a very extensive wine list - from $35 to $750/bottle - with some good options for those of us who don't need to spend $750 a bottle. Go here!

A French Bistro serving a variety of traditional fair at moderate prices, L'express provides the full french/Montreal experience. Although the calf liver dish was just OK, the bread, pickles and wine list were truly a wonderful component of the dinner. A special mention on their wine list is worth noting. Prices on wines were fair and selection was excellent. I especially enjoyed their fortified wine selections! Great service where servers came across knowledgeable, engaging and humble.

Enjoy Montreal!

Duck was dry and tasted terrible. Foia gras was stale. Service was slow.

Overall a pretty terrible experience, especially given the price.

It was hard to find even with google map but it was so worth the trouble!  Everything was delicious and my vodka martini was perfect!  And I had best bone marrow dish.  I should stop try elsewhere to avoid disappointment.  Wishing I didn't live thousands of miles away...

Reservation is highly recommended. But we ended up walking in without one because we wanted some good French food. The host was kind enough to improvise a table for us after a 15-20 min wait. This restaurant is more upscale in terms of service and food. They offer really authentic french food. We had the bone marrow, squid salad and steak tar-tar. All of which was amazing. I would def re-visit when back in Montreal.

We're so glad that we made our way to dine here on our last night in Montreal. The restaurant is small and had a French bistro feel, very cute. 

Check out my video experience https://youtu.be/_01G91sSeSU

We came on a Monday evening around 6, without a reservation, thankfully, we were there early enough to snag a table before the reservation crowds started coming in. I guess, people in Montreal dine later in the evening, similar to the French counterparts :). 

The service was friendly but very laid back, they gave us lots of time browsing through the menu. The menu was in French but they also have English menu (though there was no price list on the English version but you can compare it to the French version to know the prices). The specials were only in French but the waiter was very gracious to translate and explain them to us.

Upon sitting down, we were served baguette with butter and a jar of delicious fresh pickles with hot mustard!!! Yummmmm!!! What a great palate cleanser! So good, we had to constantly remind ourselves not to overstuff our stomach with these goodies!

We ordered the Borsch soup special and the beet salad as appetizers. Both items came out very fast. The beet salad was very pretty!!!! Colorful, fresh and oooo sooooo yummy!!!! It was one of the best salad I've ever had! Not overly dressed, just perfection! The soup had small chunks of beets, beef, carrots, cabbage and I think potatoes, topped with creme fresh...oh my!!!! It was soooooo good! It was Perfectly seasoned, hearty, a great comforting dish on such a cold day!

For the main course we ordered the pot-au-vou (stew with beef, chicken and vegetables)and quail with wild rice. Again beautifully plated and the Quail was out of this world!!! Crispy skin, perfectly seasoned, juicy, not overcooked! Delicious!!!! Certainly a dish that I would forever cherish as my last dinner in Montreal. The pot-au-vou though, was a surprise....I've had a dish with similar name, but it was cooked in some type of wine broth, similar to American pot roast. This was boiled everything in clear broth. Beautifully plated but you basically had to season the plate yourself (they gave a small jar of salt). I guess, if you want something light, this would be the kind of dish for you. The bone marrow though, was yummy! I spread the marrow on a slice of baguette, sprinkled with a bit of salt and voila, marvelous!

For dessert we shared their famous "floating island." We didn't know what to expect, but oh boy, that was one large dessert! Certainly could be easily shared with 2 other people! (Even more if you have smaller stomach and not much into sweet stuff). It's basically a meringue coated in caramelized sugar floating on custard sauce with almond pralines ... WOW! It was good but personally, not something I would order again...too big too (n i usually never complain about size! Lol) ...my hubby loved it though. Btw, if you have bad teeth, this is not a good dessert for you...lots of chewing the sugar and pralines..

Our bill with coke as drinks, came put to 95 CAD. Not the cheapest meal but great quality food that worth raving and coming back for. Highly recommended!

Brunch/breakfast menu is only until noon! 

Was expecting to get a late brunch with my friend but learned that it was only available until noon. 

We took the croque monsieur and quiche du jour; the only 2 items on the menu that seemed more adequate for brunch.

Wasn't expecting much from the quiche but oh god was it good! !! The egg was creamy and chess. ..packed with flavor.  Definitely the best quiche I've ever eaten. Also tried my friend's crowd monsieur and it was also excellent.

Definitely will be back to try other things on the menu.

This is a lovely restaurant. I'm giving it four stars because the service was excellent and for the most part, the food was tasty. We started with a warm goat cheese salad (delicious). For dinner, my husband got poached salmon with chervil mashed potatoes. The mashed potatoes were fantastic and the fish was good enough. My main (chicken with a mustard sauce) was perhaps not the best selection ... the chicken itself was a little overcooked/tough. I was expecting a quarter chicken but instead I got a very thick breast (which probably explains why it ended up tough). For dessert, we had a maple tartine, which was delicate, flavorful and not overly sweet. I'd definitely recommend giving L'Express a try. Our waiter was fairly honest when we asked for suggestions, so perhaps this is the way to go.

Boy oh boy, if a genie had given me the choice of "eat at a variety restaurants while in Montreal but not at L'Express or eat only at L'Express" I would have gladly accepted the sole L'Express experience, no DOUBT! :)

L'Express is in the St.Denis neighborhood which is the coolest part of Montreal, if you ask me (and I guess by reading this review, you kinda are). The restaurant is the shape of a train cart almost, with mostly small 2 person tables. The crowd is local and diverse: we sat near an old priss-and-proper couple sharing a romantic meal, napkins tucked into collar and all. we also bordered a pair of hip gay guys with asymetrical hair-dews and sexy auras. I'd recommend dressing up a bit, but if you aren't, it's not pretentious. Also, it is open until VERY late, which totally fits my style. We saw people mozy in at midnight, welcomed to a full menu! If you going to get wine, I recommend the half bottle, it's very 'Montreal' to do, and a bit cheaper.

As far as food recommendations, the ***bone marrow*** dish had me considering cannibalism for months afterward, every passing human reminded me of the fatty guk that I had dug out of those luscious bones! It comes with these really crunchy pieces of toast that combine perfectly with the marrow's texture. While the sea salt seemed like a good idea to sprinkle on at first, I soon realized that it overpowered the bone marrow which is perfectly fine on its own, so keep that in mind.

What I love about this place is the subtlety of its facade. There is no sign directly on it but instead its name is on the ground in the black and white tiles right before you enter. (See the picture I posted) This is one of those reviews I write hoping secretly that no one will read it, since I do want this gem to remain a gem, but if you love that French bistro feel and you don't mind forking over the extra $ for the ride, then you really should hurry over and enjoy it!

The one place on Montreal trip we felt like were out of the US.  It was great! Such a friendly bartender.  We ate at the bar since to avoid long table wait.  Great (and v. loud) atmosphere.
Steak Frites so much better than any in NYC.  Great bread and soup.  Would return!

We were on vacation in Montreal for a day and was walking around the area. Dropped by for a late, casual lunch on a Friday afternoon and found it pretty packed and had to wait 10 minutes to be seated. We sat in the front of the restaurant, but the back room looked cuter and had a sun roof and was less loud. We got the pork special appetizer, which came with the jar of tiny pickles. Delicious! Also got the celery remoulade - surprisingly refreshing. For the main we ordered the mushroom spaghetti and another special containing three different types of meat (sausage, pork, and a chicken drumstick) over a bed of seasoned beans and vegetable. The pasta was very tasty but the other entree was nothing too special. Waiter service was average as well. If you're looking for a casual lunch spot, it's a pretty quaint restaurant.

The first night I was in Montreal, I was ripped off by a restaurant pretending to be French. The second night there, I confused Montreal with Paris, due to a perfect French restaurant named L'Express. We didn't make reservations,  but this was not a problem. We walked in on a Sunday night and immediately got a seat at the bar. Perfection. The service was precise and the experience was unique. When we were seated, a jar of mini pickles and mustard that is akin to wasabi was set before us. I consumed a quarter of the jar and ate half a loaf of bread before I even placed my app order, not because service was slow, but because they were so tasty I could only inhale them. 

For an app, we had the bone marrow. The stuff looks horrid, but wow. It is served with very crisp toast and sea salt. Eat it all together and the dish is irresistible. Pure fat, but so light that it just melts away with each bite. For my main course I had the Steak and Frites (fries). Ordered it cooked medium and it was done perfectly (my dinner mate ordered hers blue and it was by all means still moo'ing). So juicy with just the right amount of redness. The seasoned juice from the steak was absorbed by some of my fries. I ate them all. All. Did I lose a touch of my dignity when they removed my plate and you couldn't actually tell what was served on it because I cleaned it so well? Perhaps. But was it worth it? Very much so. I will say that having the bone marrow and the steak was a bit much. My mouth tasted as though I had coated it with fat. Totally my fault for over doing it, but I couldn't resist. It was just that good. 

My dinner mate suggested I skip dessert and just have an apple back at our b&b. This seemed so wrong. So wrong. I went on and ordered the Chocolate Tart for dessert to help cleanse my palate. This was a let down. Not as ah-mazing as some have described it to be. A little too dense for my liking. But all in all, L'express was a perfect meal that set us back about $100 Canadian for an app, two steak dinners, two beers and a dessert.

This is a great restaurant in Montreal. The service was very good, and the food was amazing.  The price is also somewhat cheap compared to what you are getting.  
 
We had made a reservation as we had a group of 6, and it was good that we did. It was pretty busy all evening.  We ordered a few different drinks, they had a number of nice wines, good mixed drinks and good beers on tap.  

For apps, we had the smoked salmon, the bone marrow and a salad. The bone marrow was amazing. 

We had a few different dinner dishes, the hanger steak, beef tartar, a fish dish.

The beef tartar and steak frites were amazing, easily the best we had all weekend.

This place is a must!

The way I review it is if you are better value for money in all criteria, then you have 5 star. If you are value for money but good or really good - 4 stars, if you are A-OK then A-OK.

This was a solid 5 Star experience

5 star
Everything from food service to decor. Simple stuff but super tasty. We had the Octopus and lentil salad and the Grilled Salmon. 

Both super yummy. Simple but tasty ingredients. Authentic French cuisine. Great mustard and pickles.

Amazing French cuisine restaurant! Everything tastes delicious. I highly recommend coming very hungry because you'll feel very guilty not finishing everything. Please also order the floating dessert. You will not be disappointed!

Classic basic French bistro. Downside was that lunch menu doesn't start until 11:30AM on weekends, so ordering at 11:15AM means your choices are mostly just bread and eggs. Granted, they are impeccably prepared eggs, like everyone else here... and the bread is scrumptious (I'm told; I'm gluten-free)... but wish the full menu were available all day.

There is no sign, like any true great French bistro. The minute you step into the restaurant it is as if you are transported to Paris of the 1920's. The decor is classic bistro with dim lighting and old world feel. The waiters wear vests and clean white aprons and greet everyone with warmth. You just know you are going to be taken care of. 

Everyone's food at the table looked delicious, but I wasn't able to take a bit before their dishes were already half finished, so I can only comment on my own food. I had the shrimp risotto. This is not exactly French, but the French version of an Italian classic. The risotto was perfectly cooked with just enough bite to the rice to not make you feel like you are eating baby food. The shrimp were delicious and fit the saffron infused rice perfectly. 

As for dessert, I was able to sneak more than one bite off of everyone else's plate. ;) My rum baba came in what seemed like a pool of simple syrup. This made me worried because I do not enough overly sweet desserts. However, the syrup was balanced, not overly sweet or rum-y. The cake itself was almost egg bread life and soaked up the syrup wonderfully. The chocolate tart was the MOST AMAZING chocolate tart ever! Think dark, bitter sweet, creamy, rich and buttery. Good, right? Well, multiply that by 100 and this is what this tart tasted like. I would come back to just have this tart again.

Went there this summer after convincing my daily how great this pace is. Last went in 2009 and its even better than I remembered it. A gourmets delight with excellent service, ambiance and of course the meal was outstanding.

A+

Received a recommendation from our bartender at Le A Bar to check out L'Express during our visit to Montreal. He said it was the best French bistro outside of France. It sure pays to chat with local bartenders!
We were able to easily book a reservation online less than 24hours out for an early 5:30pm dinner.
Our experience was one of the best dinners of our life. Accommodating to English speakers, the staff were so top notch and organized with bringing out our dishes and taking care of our requests including recommending some excellent wines to pair with our order.
I loved how they brought out a large jar of cornichons to enjoy with your food, they went great with mustard and the pork rillette we ordered for an appetizer.
We got one item from their daily specials that might have been the best dish of the meal - Fresh tomatoes with burrata cheese and pesto. We sopped up this dish with the bread L'Express provided!
The entrees we ordered were the sea bass and hanger steak. The steak had a shallot butter on top that was outrageously good. The sea bass came with some perfectly cooked fresh green beans. Overall everything was fantastic.
This really was a five star meal in every way. L'Express will be the first dining spot I'll recommend to anyone traveling to Montreal. Big thanks to Le A Bar for giving us this tip!

My husband and I visited L'express on our first day in Montreal for lunch. Upon entering this bistro, which is nestled on a beautiful street between many restaurants and clothing and furniture boutiques, we were instantly immersed in quintessential french aromas. Smells of, herbs like thyme, butter, and slowly braising meats and vegetables. It's a bustling busy restaurant that has a very warm and cozy atmosphere with a very friendly wait staff. 

We ordered:

House salad a blend of arugula and peppery greens topped with a simple light dressing a good starter. Delicious

Vegetable soup a tomato based soup with beef broth and lots of veggies, like quash, corn. Yum

Entrees:

Croque Monseiur fried buttery cheesy toast with ham. Delicious.

Beef stuffed Ravioli. Over the top Delicious, I used my bread to sop up all the broth from my plate because it was so delicious and flavorful.

Also the restaurant has had the same menu for 30 years most of their dishes have been perfected, so don't offend and ask for substitutions. Everything looks and probably tastes delicious. People sitting next to us ordered egg salad, salmon, stewed mushrooms and liver over fries, steak and every dish looked scrumptious.

This well established classic French bistro was opened in 1979 by a young couple who were frustrated that they couldn't get a good bite to eat after working long hours in the theatre. The concept was simple, provide delicious and affordable meals to everybody all the time.
Their vision still holds true today as opening hours are from 8am to 2am on most days of the week. 
So next time you are out late and hungry, forget about poutine and greasy Chinese food, swing by l'Express! Classic French bistro food doesn't get better than this!

We ordered for starters the bone marrow and octopus salad. Bone marrow was melt in your mouth buttery good. Octopus was very refreshing and well cooked but nothing out of the ordinary.
For mains we had the raviolis - simply outstanding, bursting with flavour from the pork and mushroom filling- and the roasted quail - wow again, cooked to perfection, crispy skin, well seasoned.
For dessert we tired the 'ile flottante' - huge serving of very well whipped meringue topped with an almond brittle. 

All in all, if I lived in the area I'd be going every week!

Every time a demanding work obligation is over I need to celebrate with style my freedom. This is how we decided to book a dinner at L'Express and the visit was so enjoyable that we started planning another visit during the second course. 

First we loved the vibe of L'Express, the dynamics, the noise, the energy. L'Express is may be the most French bistro among all the bistros in Montreal, it is also an example that there is no need to be fancy and there is enough elegance in simplicity. 

Second we chose as our preferred sitting the bar. Nothing surprising, that has been always our beloved place to be in a restaurant as the interaction with the bar tenders may be priceless.... Don't miss the chance to enjoy a dinner at the bar is my recommendation and also ask for advice what wine matches better your food. I did not see a cocktail menu, but mixes are made on demand and they are good.    

Third the food is wonderful. I would not allow myself the extravaganza of eating bone marrow, french fries and steaks every day, but from time to time, oh yes and preferably at L'Express! The french fries are amazing and they are served with home made mayo. The hanger steak and steak tartare were superb. Don't get me wrong, there are some healthier choices in the menu. We also loved the home made pickles, and the extensive dessert list, and the endless digestive options, including few choices of Armagnac.

Genuine five stars and shared love!

I loved this place. It was the first time I had ever gone. The food was spectacular, the staff were wonderful and the ambiance was quaint. It was perfect.
Our waiter was extremely helpful with helping us choose the perfect win to pair with our dishes. I had the rillettes as an entrée (out of this world great!!!) and the grilled salmon on a bed of spinach as my main (Holy mother of pearl.. I still dream about it).. And because I'm a pig, I decided to try the dessert that they are "known" for; the Floating Island Dessert. It was so great that my boyfriend said (and I quote) "I should get one of these for home if it keeps you so quiet"...

A MUST TRY!

Family of four adults dining at 5:30 pm on a Thursday night. We had a reservation and got seated promptly. We had very attentive, but unobtrusive wait staff. We asked the waiter what some of his dinner and dessert favorites were and he did well by recommending the veal ravioli (bites of heaven), the Special pork (tender and juicy) and the Shrimp Risotto (rich). My son had the hangar steak and loved the peppery seasoning on it. We also tried the bone marrow and the goat cheese salad for starters, all delicious. We finished with two deserts, the profiteroles with maple ice cream and the rice pudding with the drizzled Carmel sauce both lovely despite already being stuffed to the gills. The food was outstanding and I would definitely come again. The Foodie family gives it  for service, ambience (not pretentious) and food.

I was a bit hesitant in coming here 'cause I'd rather eat at a dive with good food, than some upscale, snotty place where you get a piece of asparagus with some sauce drizzled on top.  So yes, I was a bit worried about the whole portion size vs. cost et notorious French snobbery!

However, I am happy to report that the service, from the host to the aproned waiters was not pretentious at all.  Both water/wine were refilled without prompting.  Furthermore, the portions are quite fair for the amount that you pay.  

I had the sauté duck confit and duck was nicely seasoned.  Even though duck was on a bed of greens, I left totally satisfied.  I didn't get to taste it, but apparently the shrimp risotto was really good!  If I was more comfortable (and hungry), I would've ordered an app, but didn't get a chance.  

Entrées were like mid-$20s while bottles of wine started at mid-$30s.  Not bad for a special occasion!

Tip:  Reservations are a-must!

We came to Montreal for my friend's birthday trip. We looked through Yelp and picked this highly rated restaurant to celebrate my friend's birthday. It was a big disappointment. The service was just ok. They do have menus in French and English but the one in English doesn't have prices on it. The food was meh. We ordered bone marrow, foie gras, oysters, country soup, fish soup, quail, steak tartare and pork. The bone marrow and foie gras were greasy. I am not a fan of those dishes. Oysters was fresh and tasty. Country soup was ok. Fish soup was kinda watery and weak. For the main dishes, the steak tartare was my fav. It was nicely flavored and the fries came with it were crispy and good. My friend like the quail. The sauce mixed with rice was good. The pork was recommended by the waiter but it was not as good as I expected. The pork itself was tender but the sauce is not that good. Their prices were very reasonable but I do t think I will come again. I'd rather pay a little bit more to have food that make me satisfied.

3.5 stars.

Regular french bistro to me. I have to admit I was a tad disappointed when we came here after all the hype we heard. Probably it was because we were here for brunch where the offering is rather standard and it's really hard to stand out. Seems like all the raving reviews here are on their dinners. Oh well.

Well, a classy french restaurant with executive service and fine menu!
I entered the place at 2:00 AM just to munch something. I was not expecting a warm welcome but people here are amazing and they simply get it that in the middle of the night what people are coming for.

I had a salad, which was amazing and so fresh. They give pickles, bread etc complimentary. And they are generous with it.

They offer highest grade food and wide selection of drinks. The wines selection in particular is outstanding. 
Anyway if you need excellent food in middle of the night this is your place!

I'm so glad I visited this restaurant when I was in Montreal last week. The food was fantastic. We started with the bone marrow, which was interesting but good. I had the duck confit over salad and my partner had the lobster risotto. Both dishes were absolutely delicous. The risotto was perfeclty cooked and the duck wasn't too greasy. Also, the vinigrette was really tasty and I enjoyed the texture of the salad. Definitely indulge in some dessert. The flan and chocolate tart were incredible. The prices were really reasonable.  The staff was great and you don't need to speak French.

I don't understand what all the hype is about. This restaurant is quite good but nothing special. Out of four nights in Montreal, we EXPECTED this one to be our best meal (we were told this restaurant had an international reputation!) but it actually came in third out of four. It's good quality but somewhat underwhelming as an overall experience.  

We ordered two appetizers: the pate and the mushroom tart (which was a special). The mushroom tart was AMAZING - by far the best of what we ordered. It came with arugula on top with a very tasty dressing, cheese, and ham. The balance of flavors and textures was excellent. The pate was ordinary. 

For entrees we ordered the roasted duck with red wine reduction sauce and roasted figs; and the halibut (both were daily specials). The duck was excellent -- in a very rich and flavorful sauce, nice mix of savory and sweet with the figs. The halibut  was just so-so. The halibut itself was bland and quite dry. The roasted red-pepper sauce was good but the best part about this dish was the bed of zucchini strips (cut thin like pasta). 

The atmosphere was lively and casual. The room was bright and loud. Not particularly romantic or fancy. (For example, of four nights  we spent in Montreal this was the only night we didn't get cloth napkins). The place felt more like a diner than a fancy restaurant. I didn't feel there was anything special about the atmosphere -- especially given how many other cool, cozy, romantic restaurants there are in town. The bread and butter they served was not very  good - bread was slightly dry, butter was too hard, and they did not give you small plates to serve yourself bread with.  

The service was excellent and very friendly.  However, our overall experience was just a bit underwhelming. It was nothing like the total-quality experience of other Montreal restaurants we experienced. I would say it's very good, but nothing special. If there hadn't been so much hype about this place we might have gone with more tempered expectations and enjoyed it a bit more. As it is, I would say it's a good solid place with decent food, but I have no idea why there is so much hype about it. Maybe we just ordered the wrong things.
Very friendly restaurant and a great dinner. We were delighted with every thing we ordered from appetizers to desert. The waiter was a bit slow but nothing major. A very good address!

Booked here in advance before going to Montreal cos of the reviews.
The place is as cute as a button, and feels like U are completely somewhere else.
Anyway, food wise, I had their bone marrow  to start and veal kidney mustard entrees. 
Let put it this way, I've tried bone marrow once, when we spotted Waitrose  selling them - not sure why, possible the easy we cooked it - it was super Disgusting! Maybe we didn't know how to cook it right or something...anyway the one I had in this place didn't taste/smell anything like the one I cooked!
The fat was well balance on the thin crisp bread with a pinch of salt. 
Veal kidney with mustard sauce was OK, but I won't order that again if I return. 
Finally the floating island! Amazing piece of art!!!! You got to order this even just to look at it!

This was our 3rd time eating here and did not disappoint. We chose to sit at the bar as we love chatting with the wait staff behind the bar. Had the beet salad and the risotto. Very good food, great ambiance and in a great area of town (St. Denis). Fantastic wine list. Will definitely return here.

I have been to this restaurant so many times that I lost count. Well obviously I love it so much that's why the repeated return.
Service has always been very good, professional and attentive. 
The ambience is energetic, very French, and European feel. Little tables with white paper on them, which is a classic bistro/brasserie feels. It is a smaller version of Balthazar in NYC, but the menu is much better than Balthazar. 
They have items that are hard to find i.e. Veal Liver, Veal Kidneys, Rabbit Terrine and etc. Food taste really authentic, well executed and classically presented. 
Dessert wise expect creme brûlée, profiteroles, lemon tart, chocolate tart, floating island. 
Expectation is always met with no disappointment. 
Price wise in my opinion is reasonable and fair for the quality you get. 
Will definitely return again & again, and I highly recommend this place when visiting Montreal.

3.5- L'Express is a classic French bistro and the food is classically good. However, I failed to see what the hype was all about, as the food was very good but not necessarily significantly better than any of my other Montréal dining experiences. 

Then chicken liver pate with pistachios was delicious, as was the foie gras terrine. The bone marrow was good, but a huge hassle to eat because the spoons didn't fit inside properly. Each table is given a jar of adorable little pickles and they were delicious! 

For my main, I had the quail and it was pretty good, nothing to write home about. One of my friends had the shrimp risotto and that was delicious! Someone who had the lemon sage chicken breast reported that it was incredibly dry. But if you're looking for something a little different, the calf liver was delicious!

The service was good but not terribly attentive. We had to remind our waitress to bring silverware a couple times, but I totally get that we were eating during a Friday lunch rush. 

Overall, delicious and good. I think my expectations were overhyped by all the amazing reviews and recommendations, so my actual experience at L'Express fell a little short.

A throughly enjoyable evening, in spite of the fact that they were out of the bone marrow when we arrived. 
The setting is very French with the requisite zinc bar and black and white tile floor. Loud, but appropriately so. Snug but not uncomfortable. The rilette and chicken liver pate were very good and abundant, and the cornichons are a nice touch. We had Hanger steak frites and Pot au feu. The steak was expertly cooked with restrained seasoning and a luscious herb butter. The frites were thick and served with aioli. My wifes Pot au Feu was less successful, the individual elements were very good, but they just didn't seem to come together. 
The wine list is excellent and fairly priced, although more by the glass selections would be nice. The service was spot on. Pleasant, helpful without being cloying. My glass of Haut-Medoc was off and swept away without question. 
We felt it very fairly priced with the aforementioned meals, one cocktail (a rare in Montreal, High Ball glass with plenty of Gin!) 4 glasses of wine for $120.
All in all a very nice experience, but I wouldn't call it a culinary mecca .
This place is almost always excellent, food, service, everything! Only time it's bad is Christmas week, but that's fair enough! Just go.....end of! You'll be pleased :)

L'Express is probably one of the most known restaurants in Montreal and is generally booked solid.  If you have the foresight to make a reservation, great, if not, try and get here right after it opens around 5 or 5:30.  The restaurant was just getting together and we were able to snag a table as long as we were out within an hour (or rather before the person whose table we were sitting at showed up).  I had a plane to catch so it wasn't a problem.

The main menu is in French but they have English versions.  I cannot comment on all of the food but  I'd highly recommend the duck confit salad.  The fatty duck and the light salad made for a good pairing.  The foie gras app was also good.  The foie gras was served cold, which I've never seen before, and is meant to be smeared on the bread accompanying the dish.  Prices aren't outrageous but they add up quickly.

If this place is booked try Au Pied de Cochon which is a few blocks away to the NE.  Either of these two restaurants will make your night.
Worst experience, booked it through on open table and found out it's for the New York location when got there. Nothing on the website mentioned that! Sucks!!

The quintessential French bistro but in Montreal...if you're looking for that French experience in Montreal and not in Paris you'll love this place!
Visiting Montreal and want French food put this place on your list! The food is fanatic, the service is professional and cordial and atmosphere splendid.
FonFonFon!!! vive Pari!!!!

* Still a favourite *

It has been many years since I visited L'express, and I went with a bit of nervousness as I have such great memories there.  Thankfully they lived up to my memories once again!

I had a very simple lunch of pot au feu, which was perfect in every way.  The beef was incredibly tender, the carrots were the perfect consistency, the cabbage was not overdone, the chicken was tender and flavourful, and they even included a bone with marrow.  I love marrow - it is the ultimate comfort food for me, and was a lovely addition!  It came very simply presented with the usual baguette with a nice butter, a side of mustard and a big pot of cornichon.  Simple.  Delicious.  Perfect!

I followed with my favourite dessert from many years ago, the iles flottantes.  Still just as good!  A huge fresh perfectly fluffy meringue had a beautiful caramelized crunchy coating which had a few almond slices to enhance the flavour.  This was served on a perfect creme anglaise which had just the right amount of vanilla flavour.  This lived up to my memories!

I love this spot, and am so happy to know it is still just as good!

+++
Everything about this place
Apple tart was akin to apple pie but tastier and less filling
Quail is easily the highlight of the menu (although it has poor re-heat value)

++
I enjoyed the proseco, wasn't a fan of the rose wine
Steak frites
Large portions, two people can be satiated off appetizer and dinner (and we were very hungry)
Goat cheese and chestnut appetizer was warm and delicious
Typically priced dinner (2 wines, 1 app, 2 meals, dessert, was around $100)

+
Bilingual staff
Environment is simple and romantic
Full, but not too full (where you have to wait) on a Sunday night, so you know it's good

Absolutely loved this quaint little French bistro with random Palm trees. Fantastic food for a reasonable prices. Come here for dinner or lunch. We decided to stop by for lunch, which offered its dinner menu as well. I ordered the truffled boudin Blanc, seeing that I was in Canada I was going to try all the French Canadian foods. Boy, this was a great dish with a super yummy truffled sauce and cooked root yet crunchy vegetables. I've tried boudin noir at a different restaurant the night before and that was a little off putting. Boudin Blanc here was fantastic, nothing I have eaten before. My other half ordered the mushroom ravioli. Also, a really hearty tasty dish. We decided to share the bone marrow. This was a very large portion, enough for four people! It came with tons of bread, a really big jar of pickles, and mustard seeds. 

Overall, fantastic experience. Would love to come back here for a quiet, homey, hearty dinner. Until next time, Montreal!

Great atmosphere and decor. Really reminded me and my wife of a Parisian bistro. She had the roasted quail and I had duck (might have been a special of the day). Both were tasty but I would take the quail next time.

I don't understand what's the big deal???
It's not that good
My wife ordered a Sorrel Soup and sent it back immediately - had no taste.
The fish was mediocre and the Quail was OK.
We will not come back

Our original plan of just hanging out in Quebec City went awry as I investigated the possibility of a turn around bus ride to Montreal. We booked our tickets for the bus ride and embarked on our trek to the bigger city! I tried really hard to get reservations to Au Pie du Cochon because of Anthony Bourdain. After relentless attempts, we were not able to get in! This is where Yelp helps! Looking at the myriad of restaurants, we made our way to L' Express without reservations, we walked in and were able to get a table but needed to be out by 7 because someone was smart enough to reserve a table. We were nicely greeted with a humongo jar of tiny pickles and bread,  boy were those pickles nice and sour! I started with the duck confit salad, it was excellent, with nice tender pieces of slow cooked duck meat cooked in its own fat. I then proceeded with the bone marrow. I was in heaven as my plate made its way, there were enough bones to feast the eyes! The marrow was succulent ad seasoned just right. Slather them bad boys on some toasted baguettes and you just died and gone to heaven! To drink, we tried the house local blonde which was amazing!
All in all, I am glad that we stopped in, I think you will be too!

The tartare was the best I've ever had (better than in Paris!), and the Batista was a pro. Perfectly constructed cafe au lait. This restaurant really raised the bar for a quality dining experience, and really made my trip. Great!
Vive l'Express, Bravo au chef Ghislain Roy et sa salade de bettrave. Tout est bon.
Excellent classic French bistro - does the classics well - hangar steak, etc 0plus great service and nice desserts

I made a reservation online and received a confirmation email. I found L'Express on Yelp and was very excited to try it out for a more upscale option on our anniversary trip in Montreal. 

The waitress came to our table and then multiple make waiters came over (drop off food/ water). They were professional.  We started off with the fish soup (had tomato base) and came with mini cheese toasts. Also ordered the special: stuffed zucchini with black garlic. Both were good but I wasn't blown away. 
The main course and dessert blew us away though..
Main course: fresh sea bass and green beans 
Wowza!! Deliciousness 
Croque Monsieur (melted French ham & cheese) this was to die for and I got the side salad (huge) instead of fries. 
Dessert: leave room for the raspberry vanilla macaroon (best!!) made in house
The made in house truffle was good yet rich

The black and white tile floors were very French feeling and we enjoyed our L'Express experience. Next time we might sit at the bar for the croque Monsieur, sea bass, and a FEW macaroons. Bon appetite

My husband and me visited Montreal for our honeymoon. And we choose here for our first dinner in Montreal. It was a great experience for us. The atmosphere, service and food were good. 
We've ordered warm goat cheese "bone marrow with coarse salt",  "warm goat cheese salad", "roasted quail with wild rice" and "fresh sea bass with sautéed vegetables". Roasted quail was very juicy and tasty. Spreading with wild rice, it was a brilliant combination. The fresh sea bass was sweet and tender. Both of appetizers were great. Overall it was a great experience for us.

Nestled along the myriad shops and restaurants on St. Denis, L'express is a wonderful French Bistro with terrific food and a bright lively atmosphere.  They have an extensive wine list and a compact but terrific assortment of classic French dishes.  Reservations are highly recommended, but the BF and I had no problem reserving a table the same day on the later side of dinner on a Friday night.

We both started with the green salad (which was fine), and ordered for our mains the beef tartare and the steak frites.  His tartare (which came with a mountain of fries and was ordered to be spicy) was very good; definitely a good move to get it spicy to bring out the dish's flavors.  My steak frites, however, were damn near perfect.  The meat was so juicy, flavorful, and tender, and when eaten with the herbed butter, forget it.  It was out of this world.  Dinner also included delicious crusty french bread, and the only cornichons I have ever eaten that I have truly liked (perhaps because they are served in a large mason jar which allows them to marinate in their own juices).

While the service was a bit slow and the waiters seemed a little stand-offish, the food was definitely worth it.  I would definitely return the next time I'm in town and I highly recommend a visit for anyone in the neighborhood or passing through.

Moderately priced great French Quebec cuisine.
Never been to a place like this in France, so can't really compare.
But for me, this was as French as it gets.

We tried:
Bone Marrow - very interesting.
Beef Tartare - great.
Smoked Salmon - yummy.
Some salad with cheese - I didn't try it but my friend liked it.
Apple Crumb Tarte with Vanilla ice cream - amazing.

Complimentary baguette with butter & mustard, and house pickles are GREAT.

With all the food + coffee, 2 red wine glasses + 2 beers = under $100.

Definitely the place to go when looking for a good French Quebec restaurant.

BEST SERVICE in Montreal!!!

I had read earlier reviews on Yelp and was intrigued to find out if it was a good as going to Paris. My partner, who works for an airline, and I decided for a short get away to someplace we had never been. As experienced "space available" travellers we usually "fly by the seat of our pants" so to speak and don't make set plans. With this said, we decided to venture out to L'express with no reservation. We arrived at the restaurant at about 6:30pm and enquired about a table. The Maitre'd said that there was one table reserved for 4 at 8pm, however if we could finish dinner in 1 and half hours it was ours... Sold.. 

The menu was handwritten in French, however they also have a printed menu in English, Spanish and Italian. The waiter asked us if the English menu would be of assistance... another point for service. 

Since we were on a time crunch we ordered 2 courses each and decided to wait and see about dessert. I ordered the Octopus and Lentil salad and Martin had smoked salmon... The Octopus and Lentil Terrine was light, refreshing and set the tone for the rest of the meal. Martin enjoyed his smoked salmon immensely. Next he ordered the duck con-fit on a bed of greens and green beans while I ordered the shrimp risotto. Both were absolutely magnificent! It really was like we were in Paris! 

We decided to skip the dessert as we were almost approaching the 8pm hour, however I did see some of the choices and they looked spectacular. 

I will definitely be back to this restaurant on my next visit to Montreal. Highly recommended!

My husband and I came here our first night in Montreal. We were here on a Tuesday night and even though the place was crowded, we did not have trouble getting a table. We had the bone marrow and foie gras terrine to start. The bone marrow was fine but very simple. I would have enjoyed a little onion jam or a small parsley salad to go with it. The foie gras terrine was good but very similar to other foie gras terrines I have had. My husband had a duck confit salad for his entree. It was tasty and had a nice variety of vegetables. I had the steak tartare and it came with fries. The steak tartare was good, but not that different from the tartare I have had in Chicago. The fries were kind of thick and not very crispy.  Nothing really stood out to us. Although the food did not wow us, the ambiance was nice and the service was friendly. We really enjoyed the half bottle of wine that the waiter suggested for us too. However, this place isn't cheap and for the price, I think you can find tastier food.

A hard place to review because I liked the food but I don't know if I want to come back. 

First, the service was great. The waiters explained the menu in detail and took their time, answered our questions. The dessert menu is not in English, and the waiter explained the entire menu for us.

The fish soup was flavorful. It was kind of like lobster bisque just rougher in texture and less creamy (hence the soup, not bisque). The stale bread crusted with dry melted cheese it came with actually paired pretty well. 

The raviolis and quail with wild rice I think had the same sauce (veal stock), which was nice. Just wish we didn't get both because it just seemed repetitive. Raviolis, if five of them were stacked, I would have loved it but then it wouldn't be a ravioli. 

Quail was cooked so nicely. Both the leg and breast were tender and juicy, and the wild rice added interesting firm texture to each bite.

The floating island dessert - We didn't like it at all. An interesting looking dessert with boring taste. It was just sweet. It just tasted like candy. Ate one third of it and wanted to say something.

So overall, we had a pretty good meal with great service with some standouts and some fallouts.But for the price, I could have had a better meal. A solid 3.5 stars.

This is quite possible the grande dame of restaurants in Montreal. It's French bistro done right. Everything is fresh and delicious. The wine list is fabulous. The food is excellent. The service varies between decent and deliciously surly (keeping pace with stereotypes). I'd recommend requesting the goat cheese cheesecake as soon as you sit down as they often run out.

I very much enjoyed my dinner at L'Express. It's been around for a while, and definitely has that late '70s vibe that hasn't been updated, but that's part of the charm of feeling like you're in a restaurant that's no fuss, no trends, just good classic food. The warm goat cheese salad and the duck rillette were great appetizers. The bread was perfectly chewy and crunchy, and the classic Montreal spread with the jar of gherkins and mustard were surprisingly delicious. The quail entree was fantastic- juicy, crispy skin, chewy black rice, and a beautiful presentation. My family also enjoyed the ravioli and the steak frites. If you like French food, I'd recommend this restaurant for sure.

The food was good but I have definitely had better. I wouldn't come back voluntarily. 
The waiter was quite... how do I put this... special? I decided to take the roasted quails with wild rice, so this is how the conversation went (in French and yes, I speak fluent French and so did he)
Me: Could you put less rice and more vegetables for my plate?
Him: (* *) hm.. sorry no, it's pre-portioned
Me:...  what? hm... (-.-)
Him: ya, sorry
Me...Ooookkkk... well never mind what I said then...
Him: Do you want us to put more vegetables instead?
Me: (Dumbfounded) Euh... I do prefer to have more vegetables but if you keep all of the rice, I will not finish my plate and I don't want to waste
Him: aw.. you aren't very hungry, ya sorry
Me....
Him: But you DO know it's wild rice, right?
Me: (giving all my might not to give him any sarcastic response)

SERIOUSLY????

I came here with my family after reading and hearing rave-reviews about this "institution" of a place. The service was decent, a bit slower than I had expected, but our waiter was nice and everyone was very professional and polite. We got the goat cheese salad as an appetizer which was good but not exceptional. For our main courses we had the quail and wild rice, duck confit with salad, hangar steak, and steak tartare. All were very good except my father didn't like the tartare (note this is the first time he's ever had it and he's not too partial to French food). We all enjoyed our meals and were really full - I thought the portions were very generous for a French restaurant.

The exceptional part of the evening was the dessert: the floating island which was this delicious mixture of eggwhite and caramel and deliciousness...hard to describe but the perfect size for 4 people to share after a filling meal. We will consider coming back just for the dessert!

I have heard very good things about this place and tried it recently but got highly disappointed.

Food was very flavourful and bringing us back to France, but portions are way too small (typical French for sure as well) and the service was miserable. I heard better things but couldn't get the chance to experience it fully I guess.

We went here for an anniversary dinner. This place really does feel like eating back in France. I had the steak tartar which was perfect. My girlfriend got the calf liver and she also loved it. The service was very friendly (even though we didn't speak french). Overall we were very pleased.

Classic French food at its best - unstuffy, yummy food with unstuffy, kind service.  We arrive here at 10:30 following the Opera to find a bustling restaurant with happy looking patrons fishing cornichons out of jars as they talked animatedly.

I was feeling a little self-conscious reading the French menu, but the waitstaff were nice and walked us through the specials.  *Make sure* to ask about these, as we ended up exclusively ordering from them and it was totally the way to go.

To start I had oeufs mayonnaise, and would have licked the plate if it weren't improper to do so.  Instead I mopped up every bit of mayonnaise with the delicious bread, and ate more than my share of cornichons.

My husband had the fiddleheads in mushroom sauce with pancetta and almonds.  I had never had fiddleheads before and might never eat them again unless prepared in this manner.  The dish was creamy without being heavy and the fiddleheads weren't overwhelmed by the other ingredients.

We both ordered the same special for our main dish, and went with a blended red recommended by our waiter (it paired very well, just bitter enough without feeling like an astringent).  It was pork sausage with mashed potatoes and a veal ragout.  I loved the unpretentious nature of L'Express, underscored when they served this dish with dijon mustard for the sausage.  I feel the same dish in New York would have been accompanied by some ridiculous foam of some sort (or have I been watching too much Top Chef?).  The potatoes brought me back to childhood Thanksgivings, and the sausage was rustic and homemade.  I left L'Express feeling like I had eaten an intimate supper at a rural French grandmother's table.

Weekend trip to Montreal and we wanted some french classics. Admittedly, our first attempt was for a reservation at au pied de cochon but they were booked. Called Sunday morning and was only able to get a 10pm reservation at L'express but we took it and we're glad we did. 

First, definitely make a reservation in advance. We figured it would be empty at 10 on a Sunday but it was completely packed. 

Started with the octopus salad. Perfect starter. Moved on to the foie gras terrine. It was rich, creamy and decadent. As foie gras should be. We moved on to the cured ham plate which was okay, could've done without.  Finally we had the duck confit salad and the ravioli. The ravioli was OUTSTANDING.
