We regretted not having enough room to scarf all of them down. They were rich and delicious. Definitely order them. The duck confit salad, eh. The duck had quite a gamey taste and just paled in comparison to the ravioli. Our waiter recommended a half bottle of Bordeaux which paired perfectly to our dishes. The service was excellent, the ambience was cool - not too loud and appropriately trendy. 

We would definitely return on our next trip to Montreal.

Wonderful French resto in Montreal! L'Express is a must meal when in town.

One of the few places to dine at in the area that stays open late. It might seem fancy but it's actually a very casual spot.

Terrific service, cool Parisian ambiance, and very tasty food which is well prepared. They even have a great bar to chill at and partake in a few libations. Reasonably priced all around for food, wine, and cocktails.

It was so good we stopped in here for dinner a few times while on vacation. Some of the highlights were the Country Style Soup and the Fish Soup, Grilled Salmon, Shrimp Risotto, and their amazing l'isle de caramel for dessert! Loved that dessert - just wow, and so fun to eat.

I wish I could go back there for dinner tonight!

Despite the vast selection of French food in Montreal, l'Express is French cuisine in its purest form - rich, decadent, and soaked in butter, with a jar of mini pickles on the side.  The menu is stellar, and as authentic as they come. And while I haven't tasted everything that they offer, the 5 or 6 app/entree combos that I have tried have been more than satisfying. 

Oh, and did I mention that L'Express is one of the few restaurants whose kitchen stays open past 11pm. Seriously, for a city renowned for our cuisine, this sure is a rarity. 

Bonus: the waiters are like hawks, scoping out empty bread baskets within seconds of emptying, and are quick to remedy the situation, over and over and over again.
The bone marrow was unique bit really filling for one person. Nice French atmosphere

Lively atmosphere and wonderful French bistro fare make this a must visit restaurant in Montreal. We shared a few appetizers including the sorrel soup (not a big fan), a special beet salad (very good), and I had a fish special which was also very good. Had the apple tart for dessert and it was very simple yet delicious.
Classic Bistro feel and open for late night dining. The Standards are all here and their ravioli is signature. The service was superb and extremely efficient - complete professionals.

Tried twice to make a reso at this place foot dinner. One time they asked us to hold on to conform and left us on hold until we hung up. Second time they did not even pic up the phone. I hear the food is good here, too bad I won't be bringing my business here.
REALLY nice vibe. Staff was super friendly and attentive. Not stuffy at all. The food was delicious. The decor is fun (modern/sleek bistro, if you can imagine). Best meal we've had in Montreal.

Sorry, L'express, but you did not impress me with either the quality of service, nor the quality of your food. I went to L'express past 12pm, so my options of good food in Montreal were quite limited. Let's start off with service. Our waitress didn't give a **** if we understood the menu or had any questions. To me, that's a bad signal right there. Second, the food wasn't great. The quiche was not fresh and my steak was thin and had a lot of fat in it, when I was expecting a nice thick steak. So, I ended up paying quite a penny for food that I did not enjoy. Next time, I'll be going somewhere else for sure if I'm craving good food past midnight in Montreal.

Would probably give 3.5 stars if I could but 3 is too low. It was overall a good meal but with some issues:

1) The beef tartare is the worst I've ever had and surprisingly they give a lot of it. I'm used to never having enough of it but instead we left a bunch on our plate. Not sure what the issue was. Perhaps it was a bit too warm, perhaps the meat was not high quality enough? Pass on this one.

2) Hanger steak and frites was delicious. Would definitely order again, and it was cooked exactly how I asked for it. 

3) If you are going at a busy time consider having a snack beforehand. The food took a good bit of time to come out so we ended up filling up on bread which made the meal less enjoyable when it finally came. Don't go here hungry and ready to eat immediately.

This is the restaurant that people from Montreal tell visitors to go to and also eat at themselves. It's a classic French bistro, reasonably priced, with a ton of regulars. On a recent trip, I had no less that 8 different locals tell me that it was "essential" that I go here. Why? The Wine.
The wine list is AHHmazing, heavy on French wines, especially the south of France, many bottles of which cannot be found elsewhere due to a direct relationship between the buyers and the wine makers. Furthermore, for someone (moi) who has fallen madly and in absolute bonkers in love with natural wine/ vin naturel, the menu makes it easy to pick them out, as they are denoted as (bio.) on the menu. Did I mention that the markup on the wines are extremely reasonable? I saw bottles listed on the menu sold at or below US retail cost, whereas at restaurants bottles can be marked up 200-300% plus. What a great, classic spot. I'm so glad the locals who pointed me out to this place shared the joy.

Went to this place later last night (10pm) on the recommendation of another restaurant whose kitchen closed at 10pm. Wonderful experience. We shared the rilettes l'express (chicken pate), octopus and lentil salad and warm goat cheese salad for our starters. Chicken pate came with a slice of dried apricot on it and was absolutely delicious and flavourful. The octopus was tender and the warm goat cheese salad was sublime. All three dishes were very rich and filling and probably enough for us but we were greedy and ordered a main- the chicken in lemon and sage sauce. Probably the moistest chicken breast I have ever had, the sauce was amazing too. Food came fast, service was impeccable. The cost of our meal was unbelievably reasonable, including bottle of wine- 50 bucks per person! Would 100% come back here the next time I visit Montreal!

My fiancé and I made a reservation for 9:30 on a Saturday night, but we strolled in 30 minutes earlier and they sat us at the bar. The waiter was very curt but efficient and he knew that we're tourists, so he handed us the English menu.

We started with:
Fish soup - really rich and thick which was not what I was expecting but it was quite enjoyable. It came with 4 pieces of cheese encrusted baquette which was a tad bit chewy. Overall, it was good and quite a big portion as a starter. I was pretty much good kind of full after finishing my bowl of soup.

Octopus and lentil salad - my fiancé loved this dish, it was a well balanced flavour, texture and acidity. It was again a pretty big portion but tasty!

As our main we had:
Onglet (steak frites) - I ordered my hangar steak medium rare and it was quite tasty with the compound butter. The fries was really good too, but after the appetizer I only had room for the steak. My fiancé loved the steak!

Duck confit salad - The duck was shredded on a bed of greens, and you get a good portion of the duck. It was a nice balanced dish.

Overall, my fiancé and I will be back, and perhaps share an appetizer instead of ordering one per person.

Yes! Another Montreal classic. L'express is both the most memorable and most forgettable restaurant you've ever been to. It was so memorable, that I have to write this glowing review, however, it was so forgettable that I could never remember the name, could never figure out how to search for it, or how to even describe in a somewhat unique way. And yet it is just that - unique. Oddly enough.

The whole reason I went to Montreal was to experience Europe for half the money and take in a Habs game. I took in the Habs game on a Saturday, and had Sunday night to have my romantic poor-man's Europe experience. L'express delivered.

From the outside, this place is completely non-descript and somewhat forgettable. You could walk by it on Rue St. Denis and choose a thousand other restaurants over it in pretty quick fashion. But, if you come in from the ridiculous winter cold, you get a totally wonderful experience. L'express is, in my opinion, the ultimate French bistro. Not that I've ever been to France, but if I had to paint a picture of what the ultimate French bistro in France would and should look, sound, and feel like, L'express would be it. Checkered floors, a long, classic bar area, and a narrow table-clothed dining area. It's fine-dining, but rough enough that you picture some poor, disaffected artists eating frites in the corner. We sat at the bar, and the bartender spoke absolutely NO english. Perfect. 

We ordered a small glass of the house red, which was $5.00 CAD. Awesome. I think the house red was still a French red. Don't see that much anymore. This being a French bistro, I went with the hangar steak frites, so I could try and compare it on even terms with the more faux-french american bistro's I'm used to. Perfect. The hangar steak was wonderfully cooked in the simplest of preparations, the frites were undeniably wonderful, and the whole meal was delivered as efficiently as possible with as much charm as possible from the french-speaking bartender. I also remember eating some of those cornichons in the picture, though I'm fuzzy on how that came about. Maybe it comes with their totally awesome french table bread?

Overall, L'express is fast, affordable, romantic, poetic, and delicious. It's like having a dream about Montreal more than actually being in Montreal.
Simply fantastic array of cuisine.  Ambiance. Kitchen is open late!

Les rillettes etaient mauvaises (de la bouillie), le steak tartare etait horrible (pas d'echalotte aucun gout), la soupe de poissons (pas de fenouil, de la puree, tres mal faite), la mayonnaise...la mayonnaise... mauvaise mais mauvaise...
Enorme deception, cet endroit a perdu tout son charme, aucun interet, je le deconseille fortement.

When traveling on business I search for restaurants with a bar and superb food. L'express filled that need. Yes, it is a certain business tourist destination, but what I really liked is being treated like a queen, served with perfect wine pairings and the bartenders wonderfully delicious french accents. The fish soup was delightful and the company was even better.

A very traditional French restaurant. We started off with the chicken liver pate appetizer, which was delicious. My husband had the chicken and I had the spaghetti with mushrooms, both of which were very good. For dessert he had the apple and blueberry crumble and I had the crème caramel a l'orange. The service was excellent and the ambience was really that of a old French bistro in Paris.

Déçu des déjeuners ! Je sais bien que l'Express n'est pas une place pour les déjeuners, mais le choix n'était pas grand, j'avais faim en sortant et de plus la serveuse avait pas l'air trop aimable et serviable. J'y retournerais pas pour les déjeuners mais plutôt pour les lunchs ou les soupers.

I was never a big fan of the dinner menu but the breakfast is a fantastic value in Montreal.  Some of the best scrambled eggs I've had in Montreal (easier to screw up than you think).  Service with a smile.

Gets a little pretentious in the evening.

perfectly traditional French bistro; classic French food without the super expensive prices; menu is in French;  can't get much better; been outstanding for years in montreal; you must save room for dessert

Definitely a memorable experience! 

Came here for brunch and was lucky enough to chance upon what we were told was the last unreserved table for two. Service was friendly, helpful, accommodating, and quick, and I loved the old-school, elegant bistro ambiance.

Food was absolutely delicious! The French toast and scrambled eggs were amazingly fluffy, and the sausages, introduced as "house-made", were flavourful and not at all greasy. 

The café Americano was rich, and the orange juice tasted extremely fresh, probably even freshly squeezed!

An excellent experience!
Highly recommended (although probably a good idea to make reservations just in case), and would definitely return!

The food was mediocre at best.  The worst escargot excuse I have ever tried.  It was cold!! Wtf?  The rest of our meal was ok.  I enjoyed the scallops and the rabbit... The service was good and the waiter was very knowledgeable and that is one of the reasons they are not getting 1 star.  I do not know why this place is talked about and rated so highly!! I would not recommend this place to anyone who enjoys good food.  Another benefit is that they are open so late...

If you ever want to have a decadent lunch or dinner by yourself sometime, come here, sit yourself down, order the bone marrow starter, the steak frites, a glass of wine and then let a completely sensuous eating experience unfold.

After hitting the Sri Aurobindo store down the street and my mind still immersed in the rarefied spiritual air of Hindu futurist philosophy, I found myself in this part of town yesterday and realized it had been awhile since I had been to L'Express, easily hands down one of the best French (as in from France) bistros in town. 

You will find all the old stand-by classics of any French bistro or brasserie whether here or in Paris, homemade mayonnaise, chicken liver pate, bread, baguette slices, cornichons (gherkins), French onion soup gratinee, calf liver, steak tartare, steak frites, profiteroles, creme brulee, cheese plates, extensive wine and digestif lists, a bar full of brass fixings, mirrors, lively conversation happening everywhere, and a general air of conviviality. 

Yesterday we had the first snowfall of the winter and I was craving something comforting, warm and rich. The bone marrow starter hit the spot. Unctuous, rich, decadent and probably very bad for you, you can't eat something like this every other day. Served up in its bone, with toasted baguette slices, this is a treat and can rival a filet mignon in its richness and taste. (I'm just surprised how bone marrow has suddenly become an "It" item in recent years when we've been eating it for centuries in Muslim India in the form of Nihari, a super-slow cooked curry soup full of bone marrow and meat). 

The steak frites came with homemade mayonnaise and a slice of parsley butter melting all over the steak. Again, perfect. There was absolutely no way I was going to be able to have a dessert particularly the famous floating island so I settled on a single scoop of lemon sorbet instead to offset the richness of the meal.

Attentive and friendly service, wonderful food, great lively atmosphere, you'd be hard-pressed to find something as established and classic as L'Express.

Best French Bistro!

Dude. It was all about the duck when I came. Duck pâté. Duck confit. OMG. Duck fat is amazing. AMAZING. I definitely have to agree with other customers, that the fois gras was freaking awesome. It was a hard choice though, everything on the menu looked so good. They have lots of pickles. Maybe I just don't know what's going on, but part of the service is a huge jar of pickles they set on your table. Kinda random, but great if you're a pickle lover.

Tips: Fully stocked bar. Knowledgeable staff.

This is one of the most acclaimed french bistros in Montreal and it looks like one has walked into one of the bistros in 1980s. The decor and ambience is exceptionally preserved from that era. 
Having said that, it is not a romantic place- the tables are set too close together, it is a very loud place and the menu choices are very limited and rigid.
This establishment requires reservation and we got a table at 9:30 pm. I hate going to restaurants after 8pm as the servers seem to be exhausted and over worked and it seems like a task to ask them questions about the menu or wine! Plus the best desserts are sold out!!
Anyhow, we were there- shown to our table which was soo close to 2 other tables. We had 3 servers- one to take our order, another to serve and refill bread, butter and pickles ! And another one to get our food. 
There are not many vegetarian or chicken based options here. So we ordered a spaghetti, a soup and a thai cauliflower dish. Lets say, we were hungry and the food was hot and the wine was good!
I have had better food at other places in Montreal and this place just did not cut for me, inspite of all the hoopla!

I wish I could just focus on the food and move on but this is a review on over all experience. Let me start off by giving you fair warning 'DO NOT go here any later than 10pm' they have literally nothing left on the menu that's available other than the days left overs like  soups, some pasta dishes and basic chicken or fish. If you have your eyes and belly set on the coveted 'marrowbone with sea salt or quail' prepare to be disappointed. 
 
To add insult to injury we had a snobbish, stuck up French speaking waiter who completely ignored our existence. For the first time in a long time I felt like my skin color was to blame and my lack of the French language came in the way anyway I brushed it off but it was enough to make me sit there feeling pretty uncomfortable and disappointed. 

The star of the night was the  creme brûlée.

L'Express is a staple/classic in Montreal - it's been around since 1979 so you know it's legit when it's been in business for so long. The fact that it's almost always packed and there's always wait says a lot about the restaurant. Their steak tartare is fantastic and so is their steak and frites and bone marrow. Most people return for the experience - the restaurant is known for being really classic and old school, not super modern or pretentious and I think that's what why they have such a loyal customer following. Most new restaurants are hip and trendy whereas  L'Express has always stayed very much the same (food, decor, ambiance) and it's comforting and nostalgic for people to return to something they grew up / are familiar with.

A Classic French Bistro!! Loud inside, but I loved it! It was like a trip to Paris only in N America.

We were on a family vacation, and I remembered an Anthony Bourdain episode where he ate here. I checked the Yelp reviews and made a reservation, which I highly recommend as far in advance as you know.

Everything was wonderful, appetizers, salad, and entrees. A few bottles of wine and a lot of money, but worth it for a true Montreal experience.

One really fine and excellent French bistro! Loved my escargot and steak frites! Get all your French favs here! I loved feeling I was transported over to Europe. It was a fantastic dinner with my boyfriend, super romantic and the best start to our Montreal trip!

I have been wanting to have a meal at L'express after reading all these Yelp reviews. I guess setting my expectation too high left me a little disappointed. 

Making a reservation using Opentable was just so convenient. I was though really surprised  that the restaurant was not busy on a Sunday afternoon. 

But I doubt I going to have what we ordered for lunch regularly as I can feel my arteries clogging up... 

Bone Marrow, Veal Kidney, Croque-Monsieur were all quite heavy and I was ready for afternoon nap after my lunch! Those pickles on the side though was delicious as it helped with my digestion and I just couldn't stop eating those!

Service here was excellent. The deco and vibe is classical French Bistro.

But I just not feeling it... maybe I was just too full after all these eating. Or maybe I should go all the way and order foie gras instead!

Having lunch here was the highlight of my rainy day. The atmosphere is chic and lively and the food was excellent. The tables by the window would be what I consider the prime seats, as the natural light coming in was very nice contrast against the black & white tiled floors and deep red walls. The beet salad was possibly the best one I've ever had- many different kinds/colors of beets and surprisingly a few carrot and mushroom bits thrown in for fun- but what really delighted me was that the slivers of cheese on top were slightly warmed. The quail over wild rice was very tender, though it could have used some more salt or seasoning (I added). Profiteroles with maple ice cream in creme anglaise was a great end to the meal and didn't feel heavy. All this plus a glass of wine and a cup of tea  felt decadent but fairly priced for what was received.

My first visit for dinner was practically perfect and Sunday brunch did not disappoint either.

Technically, we arrived just after brunch service ended but there were plenty of menu options that worked for a brunch type meal so we were very happy.

Service is swift yet friendly. The decor is great; right out of Paris in the best possible way. I highly recommend making a reservation as they can get very business, especially on weekends.

The house made cornichons are a highlight of any meal here and be sure to peruse the wine menu for some great "biologique" options.

While it seems kind of "hypey" I'd say that L'Express is still a must try when visiting Montreal, I know I plan to make a visit every chance I get!

Hidden gem in Montreal! Love this place. Bone marrow is fantastic and you can even feel the food dancing on your tongue!!! Grilled quail is so good! The wild rice is tasty and the floating island dessert makes a meal perfect ending

My first night ever in Montreal- of course we need to start our little trip off right with a visit to a French bistro popular with those in the know (obviously I am not talking about myself here.) 
We had reservations for 10 pm and arrived a few minutes late due to a subway glitch. The Maitre d' took our coats and we were seated immediately, and I have to say, we received nothing but excellent service before, during, and after our meal. First of all, we had about three waiters attending to us. Our main guy was patient with me and my lack of knowledge regarding the French language (and everything was spelled out for me in English on an alternate menu as well.) We enjoyed wine and baguette with a-m-a-z-i-n-g butter (I promise to not wax poetic on the butter, but again, AMAZING) while waiting for our meal. Another waiter kept our water glasses full and brought us a mason jar full of gherkin pickles and mustard to enjoy while waiting for our salad. Now I'm sure this is some French bistro custom, but it's like they spied on me while I was snacking by myself one night and made note of it for our upcoming visit. Yummy. 
We ordered the warm goat cheese salad to share, and I ordered the shrimp risotto (with visions of Rachel Z. salivating dancing through my head)  while my boyfriend had the duck confit sauteed over a spinach salad with green beans (or haricot verts, if you will.) Everything was delicious, luxurious, and buttery. Our waiter was absolutely charming and didn't make me feel like a bumpkin (impressive, considering my reaction to the pickles), plus, he had a sense of humor, making a melodramatic show  of reading the menu while my boyfriend entered his tip on the portable debit machine. 
We had the profiteroles for dessert, and while I wasn't wildly impressed with them, it was definitely a solid dessert and the chocolate sauce they came in was delicious. It was a pricier meal but not ridiculous, and certainly worth the money and the freezing trek from the subway. Bon appetit!

I'm so disappointed.  I don't even know where to begin.  My initial excitement was quickly squashed right when I walked in the door.  From the reviews I've read on this place and Bourdain's "The Layover" highlights on this place, I wasn't going to leave Montreal without eating here.  The hubs and I were hungry enough to eat dinner at 5pm and figured we would probably avoid the dinner rush since we didn't have reservations.  

NO RESERVATIONS (not the Bourdain experience)
Once we stepped foot in the door, the snobby older man (which I saw in all the pictures so he was probably "somebody") asked if we had reservations.  When we said "no", he gave us a look, flipped through his reservation book, and took his time.  Terrible first impression for customer service.  The phone rang and that's when he started getting irritated with whoever was on the other end of the line trying to change their reservations.  Eventually a shorter older lady came by and asked us if we had reservations.  Again, we said, "no".  

IN THE BACK
Eventually they give us a table WAY in the back of the restaurant.  Normally, I don't care about things like that.  However, it was 5pm, and out of the 20+ tables in the front of the restaurant, only two were taken (by two couples).  The table we got in the back of the restaurant was right next to another Asian couple and other 6-8 empty tables.  My guess is that they didn't have a reservation either.  Hm.  The strangest thing is that before we walked into the restaurant, there was a white couple outside the restaurant looking at the menu and deciding on whether they were going to go in.  Eventually they did and my husband's guess was that they didn't have a reservation either.  Guess where they got seated?  YUP - in the front of the restaurant with the other white table.  I will end my rant here and go onto the food and service without making any conclusions.

SERVICE
Once we got seated, no one came to our table for a good 12 minutes.  It got to a point where my husband was going to get ready to leave.  Because he knew I so desperately wanted to eat here, he was willing to stay.  Eventually, the waitress (the older lady from the beginning) came by for our order.  I ordered the Steak Frites and asked for it medium and the hubs the Quiche with salmon and spinach.  About 2 minutes later, the waitress came back and asked how I wanted my steak.  I reiterated that I wanted it medium.  

FOOD
My Steak Frites - Well, it sure wasn't medium.  In fact, it was quite well-done.  There was nearly no sign of any pink in that flank.  I found it ironic that the waitress came back a few minutes after taking my order to see how I wanted my steak cooked.  Apparently it doesn't matter how you order it because you're going to get it well-done.  Thankfully the fries were very good.  That's probably what scored them one star on this review.  The Quiche came out and it was not a salmon and spinach quiche.  In fact, it was mushroom, leeks, and ham in the quiche.  Somehow salmon and spinach must have gotten lost in translation. Thankfully, the quiche was delicious (one more star for them) but the salad accompanying it was drenched and salty.    

OVERALL
I'm sorely disappointed with L'Express on so many levels.  I can't recommend the food or the service.  I understand people say it's a true French dining experience. However, after being in Paris several times, I can't say this was anywhere close to what I experienced in France.

A highlight of my every visit to Montréal, L'Express offers a unique combination of excellent food, lively energy, and effortless chic that is unavailable elsewhere in North America. If you need a torchon de foie gras at 2 a.m, look no further.

I've been eating, drinking, and hanging out at L'Express for over 10 years now.

It's my favorite restaurant in Montreal.

Bye now.

My boyfriend and I went to L'Express for our anniversary. Unfortunately, I had hyped it up to a point where we were both slightly disappointed. I had gone before, and remember adoring the ambience, the service and the food. We ordered the mini oysters as an entree and both almost spat them out into our napkins. The oysters tasted and smelled awful! 

The main dishes were good, I had the "onglet de boeuf au beurre d'échalottes" and my boyfriend ordered the "confit de canard." We both finished our main dishes. The service was fine, nothing over the top. We did end up pouring our own wine a few times, but that doesn't bother me much.

Overall, the restaurant isn't BAD, but nothing compared to what's new and now expected in Montreal's food scene.
Delicious no nonsense french bistro food. If you want a guaranteed satisfactory meal this is the place.

We spent our last night in Montreal at L'express and what a wonderful choice that was!  1) I love the decor! 2) the service was great! 3) the food hit the spot!  
Reading some of the reviews, i can see why diners might not be on the same page.  For me, I really enjoy french food and perhaps that's still a novelty for me.. maybe I'm easily pleased? either way, i did have a wonderful dining experience here~

we got the octopus salad to start.  the portion was very generous! i enjoyed it very much and didn't expect it to be so filling! it also comes with a jar of pickles~ omgggg they were so mini and good! a very good appetizer by itself! 

then i got the special rabbit risotto.  it was delicious! but i can't say that it was phenomenal.  maybe that's the nature of rabbit.. and risotto.   it was a creamy dish.  everything fell into place with no loose ends.  i was holding my stomach by the end of my meal.. on the other hand, my boyfriend got the steak frites and he commented how the portion was smaller than expected and it was just an-ok steak.  guess when it comes to steak, it's still better to order at an american steakhouse lol

so overall, i would give it a solid 4 star.  i would love to return and try other things.  not so sure for my boyfriend though.

Five stars for the young man who brought us bread at least 10 times, cleared plates and brought our food and drinks out in literally seconds. Bravo.
Foie gras, chicken liver and my quail was perfect! Steaks were a bit bland honestly, chewy, undercooked. The experience however, the bread, butter, pickles, drinks - all in all bring this spot to a 5!

Incredible, incredible, incredible;  everything this place is touted to be.  Our first day in Montreal for my wife's birthday and foodie tour, we went to L'Express for a late dinner.

Cool, small, unassuming place with exceptional service and pure food to die for.  We shared the salmon tartare and sliced octopus salad for appetizers.  They were both amazing.  I had the hangar steak (perfectly cooked meat with crisp fries) and wife had the poached salmon.  One of the highlights of our week.
it was good, the soup I had was a bit too sour, loved the ambiance makes you feel like in a bistro in Paris, would defintely go back again to try the rest of menu.

Such a lovely classy bistro. We were visiting out-of-town and wanted to have french food as our final meal in the city. The service here was great, they were so attentive to us. 

We appreciated the jar of cornichons that you get from the beginning. 

For appetizers, we had the foie gras and the fish soup. I felt like the price of the foie gras did not match up to my expectations - that is my only complaint. 

The highlights were clearly the entrees! We loved the homemade ravioli and the steak tartare with frites. The homemade ravioli was full of flavour, crammed with the veal and mushroom filling. But not too heavy. And the steak was delicious, well balanced. 

And we ended the meal with lemon sorbet which was perfect as well.

What a lovely, lovely restaurant. It somehow tiptoes the line between no-frills and fancy. The fancy is in the menu, which is where it counts the most. They have a very extensive lunch menu, with all of the classics.

We shared the bone marrow between the four of us, and it was delicious. Perfect example of melt-in-your-mouth goodness. They also give you a giant jar of cornichons to snack on, which is nice.

For my entree, I had the quail with dirty rice. It was served with romaine lettuce, so you could make a scoop out of it. The rice was great, but the quail... the quail was was amazing. Five pieces of perfectly cooked poultry.

I also tried my buddy's steak frites, which were also really good. A bit heavy though, but that's to be expected.

This was our last meal in Montreal before heading to the airport, so we moved to the bar to have some coffee before we left. The host (or manager? or owner?) came by and offered us shots of this coffee liqueur in celebration. She did one with us as well. When we asked how much we owed her for the espresso, she told us to just get out of there. Lovely lady.

In terms of going away meals, you'd be hard pressed to find a better option than L'Express.

The perfect Montreal-French bistro. Traveled for the steak frites and haven't stopped thinking about it one week later. The service was impeccable: warm smiling faces enthusiastic to describe a dish if requested in between changing courses with the precision and grace of a jukebox switching between two great records. Wonderful wine list with plenty of bottles between 35-50 as well as dozens of options (even if just to glance at) above that price and half-bottles as well. The steak was tender, well portioned and the pat of shallot herb butter perfect to spread between the grilled crust and crispy fries. We indulged with the maple tart and Quebec apple ice cider to cap of a Monday evening vacation night. Will be our first stop next time we are in the city.

I had read some reviews while in Montreal but didn't intend on coming here until the place we had in mind was actually not close to the Sherbrooke subway stop we got off of (damn you google maps!). So walking up the cute street of St Denis, we decided to come here. Thankfully at 8pm on a Saturday night we were able to get seated within 5 minutes due to the table not having anyone next until 9:15pm. Lucky for us.

The bottle we got was from Chile and was only 21CAD. We looked around and that's what everyone was boozin' off of so we knew it had to be decent. We were sitting in between two of the cutest old couples. One was drooling at my dessert, the other was talking about using the internet to book hotels (nice!). 

For appetizer we got the bone marrow, and it was SO amazingly juicy, fatty, and delicious. Hurt so good. We ordered the chicken in mustard sauce and the duck confit salad. Both were tender and flavorful - consistent delivery. This altogether with the vino made the experience even better. The chocolate tart was rich, but just what I needed to wind down.  The service was great -- had about 3 different guys wait on us throughout the night.

The great thing is that it is open until 3am, you don't see that much. Topped off the night by checking out a jazz club near by. The neighborhood in that area is so cute. So much shopping I wish I could have done! I'll have to come back for more next time.
Peu importe l'heure, le moment, la journée, c'est eeexcellent! Les raviolis aux champignons, coup de foudre.

came here because it was the only place open for dinner at 11:30pm on a Friday that wasn't a fastfood place, but it may very well have been, prices were on par with nice French restaurants but food was straight out of a cafeteria line. would only come back if I were drunk and hungry. thanks to the Canadian-US exchange rate, the damage was less.

Classic old school European restaurant. A lot of tourists but still, I hear, a local institution. Oysters were best I had in my life. The rest were very good but not great: duck, chèvre chaud, and saumone tartar. Amazing wine list. Very happy with our meals.

This may not be the best place to eat in montreal, but the preparations are consistent, made from fresh ingredients and flavorful. We wanted to eat characteristically canadian french on our visit and were looking for a delicious lunch. A casual, but elegant restaurant, this place fit the bill. With your meal, you get complimentary cornichons, tart and crunchy, along with warm, well-made french bread. 

Here is what we ate:

Soupe Poisson (fish soup) - thick & flavorful, with a creamy tomato base that complements the seafood flavors, it comes with a side of cheese crusted toast; photo: http://www.flickr.com/photos/bluepupae/3139323889/in/set-72157611620272667/

Brandade - a salty fish & potato puree dip that is great with bread; photo: http://www.flickr.com/photos/bluepupae/3139324637/in/set-72157611620272667/

Country Soup - a hearty vegetable soup with clear broth with lots of flavor, warmth and is good for you too; photo: http://www.flickr.com/photos/bluepupae/3139324939/in/set-72157611620272667/

Croque Monsieur - i didn't try this, but it comes with a salad, and was tasty according to my bf's sister who had it. photo: http://www.flickr.com/photos/bluepupae/3140154790/in/set-72157611620272667/

Lobster Risotto - rich, creamy, delicious with chunks of lobster; photo: http://www.flickr.com/photos/bluepupae/3140155484/in/set-72157611620272667/

Duck Confit w/ salad - moist, seasoned duck meat is balanced by a nicoise type salad of lettuces & green beans and sprinkled with bits of bacon; photo: http://www.flickr.com/photos/bluepupae/3140155842/in/set-72157611620272667/

Crème Caramel à L'orange -  a flan-like custard in a sweet, light caramel with hints of citrus

Chocolate Tart - rich, dark chocolate; like eating a tart made of truffles

The waitstaff was friendly and not annoyed we spoke english. Then standard menu offers translations in six different languages, and our waitress helped with the specials, which are on an insert.

I had originally envisioned this restaurant to be highlight meal of my Montreal trip.  

While the history and the decor of the restaurant is very nice, the food quality did not live up to the high expectations.  On its own, the food is fine, but not compared to the expectations and reviews.  We had the green salad, the fish soup and the steamed bass.  The soup tasted good.  The steam bass was above average and the presentation of the dish was average.  Maybe the restaurant is better known for their other meat dishes.

I probably won't be adding anything new to what's been said about this place - but wanted to add my two cents.

The steak and frites is to die for!! It's one of those things one MUST try while in Montreal!

This is one of those places where they pay careful attention to detail and everything, from appetizers, to main course to dessert are delightful.

Reservations are essential. Call a couple of days in advance and if you're planning to visit on Saturday - reserve a week prior!.

Can't wait to come back here next time I'm in town!

This place is a classic French bistro on St. Denis that has solid service and food. In terms of value, ambiance, service and food quality this place is a must try when you are in Montreal. Will you be blown away? Probably not. But you will be charmed and satisfied by the food and service. 

Love everything from the bread basket, complimentary cornichons and mustard and the lovely French dishes. Bone marrow is great, their French fries are excellent and I loved the salmon with beurre blanc sauce. Lots of wines to choose at all price points and they serve an excellent port here.

We ordered 2 starters, 2 mains, a bottle of wine and a glass of port and it was all under $175 including a generous tip. We left the place stuffed, a little tipsy and oh so happy.

Great bistro feel, awesome bistro food. Went early with the little one and had a great meal, while she slept. Some highlights - the octopus and lentil salad, liver mousse, sorrel soup to start were all excellent. For main courses, the duck with chanterelles was a hit, as was the house ravioli - which was out of this world. For dessert their l'isle flotant was big enough for 4, but good enough that one could justify eating it. 4 people, 3 courses, 2 nice bottles of wine ~ $350 tip in.

This is the best restaurant ever.

We've come to Montreal twice, eaten here twice on both visits, and wherever we travel, we compare every good restaurant to L'Express.

I don't want to hype your expectations, but if you come here, simply expecting a nice meal with good service at a not-so-high price, you will have a good time. You may want to come back again, and you should. Because when you leave Montreal, maybe not the first week after, maybe not the first year after, you may very well find yourself comparing restaurants in your home town - or in other cities you travel - to L'Express.

There are fancier / hipper / I don't know what. If ever a restaurant could make you want to move to a city, L'Express is that restaurant. Because you could afford to eat here regularly, you would want to become a regular, and just the thought makes me want to pack up my life and learn to speak Quebecois! But, like you, I have a real life far off in another city.

So make L'Express your home base while in Montreal. Come for brunch one day, dinner another. If you are so lucky as to have a third meal here . . . TMI alert: I was driving to work a few days ago, steaming about being in traffic, and I remembered that there was the day when I walked up Rue St Denis to L'Express and had lunch. #goodtimes

This place is reflective of it's namesake - l'express. There's a small list of dishes to choose from so you can quickly decide. Your order will arrive accordingly swiftly. 

They haven't changed their small menu for as long as I can remember but what they do have, they manage to do it well. And it's always pleasant to drop in for a quick bite. Think of a "diner" experience with much better and cleaner food that's well put together. Their meats can be overlooked. And that's often the problem when I go. But everything on their menu is solid. Take a look at the menu before you go. If there's anything you're in the mood for, this place is sure to satiate it.

What a great place! My friends and I had dinner here New Years day, and I'm so happy we did! The service was very attentive as well as helpful. Our waiter made a few suggestions before we ordered and they were on point. I started with the bone marrow appetizer and i must say i didn't know what to expect having never had this before. The flavor was sweet, almost smokey. I loved it, but the texture took some getting used to.  For my entree i ordered the steak tartar (another recommendation) and it was phenomenal! Extremely flavorful and an extremely generous portion. I would actually recommend ordering this as an appetizer for the table as i couldn't finish the dish myself. 
      If you make it to Montreal,  this is a must!

Everything we've had on the menu is excellent. Service is super efficient, and with a smile. The onglet was exactly how I like it. Salads were fresh and delicious. Carpaccio was beautiful and delectable. The quail was succulent, on a bed of wild rice. Desserts did not disappoint. Trying the Ile Flottante with caramel is a must. The chocolate tart (made with 70% from Tanzania) was about the best I've ever had. Lemon tart was smooth, balanced in flavor, and topped with a sumptuous dollop of white chocolate ganache. There's something for every budget on the wine list. Old fashioned French brasserie atmosphere and service in Montreal. Try it, you won't regret it.

Best place to eat good late at night - they close at 2am on some days. The Ravioli Mushrooms and the Croque-Monsieur are a must every time. The alcohol prices are pretty amazing also, they about 0.5 times the retail price - which is the best in the city. 

All the deserts are regal, if you lucky enough try the Baba Au Rhum or the Cheesecake.

We came here as a secondary option and very glad we did. At first looking at the menu was a bit intimidating since I am not a French speaker but our waiter gladly presented us with an English version of the menu. 

Eats:
Appetizer - Some sort of mushroom with roasted potatoes and a poached egg on a bed of lettuce. Great start of the meal. The portion was perfect for sharing and all the mixed favors does good on a pallet. 
Entree - Baked quail with Quail eggs and wild rice.....delicious. The quail was perfectly cooked, quail egg was a good touch and the wild rice was just cooked al dente 
Dessert - Floating island which is a caramel shell on caramel sauce with a side of honey roasted almonds.....this was good but I would try something else next time. Presentation is nice but nothing special with the dessert. 

Likes:
- service was excellent. The staff is very friendly and for the non French speakers they are willing to translate anything you have in question. 
- side of sour pickles was a good touch
- big wine menu with about 4 different types of beer to try

Dislikes:
- this is being picky but the house bread would be better warm

Overall I am glad we came here. It was nice they close at 12am for your late night option.
We got the "steak" tartar and the duck fois gras and it was not what we expected. The steak was actually minced beef. We sat at the bar as this restaurant needs reservation

Spectacular service and atmosphere. Food was great and they have an excellent wine list. Prices were reasonable for a restaurant like this.

Pro tip: MAKE A RESERVATION. They will immediately turn you away if you try to walk in. We went on a Sunday night and there were still a lot of people waiting to be seated after 10pm. A man came in with his wife, the maitre d asked if he had a reservations and upon hearing no said, "Absolutely not, good night." That's all you'll get if you don;t make a reservation.
Service was lovely, fantastic food. I really enjoyed the atmosphere of the place.

This was my first experience ever eating real French food so I can't say I know a whole lot about the subject. However I am sure that many people are in the same situation and are unknown on what to expect.

I came here with my husband (made reservations of course) and was very worried about his meat and potatoes attitude. Due to that we skipped an appetizer much to my disappointment. I had the sautéed duck confit salad and he had the homemade raviolis. My dish was good, didn't quite blow me away I think there wasn't enough flavor or variety to it. However the homemade raviolis came out and my husband looked at them like "what the f*** is this" because it wasn't Italian.  However one bite quickly changed his mind as they were melt in your mouth good. A little salty for the dish.

If I had known there there was a counter I would've requested a table in our reservation but the best English speaking employee the bartender who was very nice was there. 

Again to my disappointment my husband made me skip dessert so our meal came out quite cheap. I would say if you are sitting at the counter it's definitely a more casual vibe but at the tables it seemed a bit more upscale. 

Can't wait to come back on our next visit and get an appetizer and dessert in!

3.5 stars

TL;DR: Decent place to visit while in Montreal, good for a small plate bite. Decent for groups/dates. Reservation recommended! (just seems like the norm in any French restaurants in Montreal)

Is it just me or I felt like there has not been any single bad dining place in Montreal? L Express is no exception - although this is not a necessarily a 5 star place to eat yet even the less than stellar restaurants actually are pretty good. It's just one of those things with French sophistication - the standard bars are pretty high across the board.

Managed to visit this place during one of our restaurant hopping in Montreal the past thanksgiving. We tried to come without reservation on one of the weeknights around 8ish and we were told that they had no place until 10 PM, so we decided to take place our names down and hung out at different place in the meantime.

So when we came back, we have already had some bites by then..so my friends and I decided to share shrimp risotto and the homemade raviolli! Food came out pretty quick, the shrimp risotto actually turned out not to be my favorite dish (2 out of 5), texture was a little off as the rice was more solid/starchy than more like a porridge consistency. And the vegetables inside it were still a little tough. The homemade ravioli  with mushroom was a totally different story. it probably was one of the best mushroom raviolis I ever had anywhere. The gravy that was part of the dish elevated the dish to another level. (5 out of 5). Another thing was that the portion was a little too small than my liking. It probably was for the better that we did have a small bite before coming here. 

So there you have it. Average rating = 3.5 stars.

Out concierge was supposed to make a reservation but didn't.  Restaurant accommodated us but maitre d made sure to tell us that we did not have a reservation.  Seems like restaurant was more attentive to Upper East side NYC customers than us.   Food was just ok.  Our waiter only came to take our order and and bring the check.  Very disappointed.   Terrible end to a fun trip.
Exactly what you want in a bistro. The staff is superb. Sitting at the bar is a genuine pleasure.

My husband and I came to L'Express for dinner during our visit to Montreal. This place was highly recommended by our friends. 
We made a reservation the same day and were seated promptly. I liked the ambiance in here. The servers are definitely hustling and working hard but I found them to be very friendly, attentive and professional. 
We ordered the Duck tartare, the ravioli, quail and the floating island dessert. All the dishes were delicious- each dish was seasoned well and was very comforting after a long day of exploring the city. 
Overall a pleasant dining experience and perfect for date! Would return again.

with a handwritten menu, this place has all the charm and bustle of a real french bistro.

be sure to be adventurous and try out their specialities.

my father and i enjoyed the following at lunch:

1. the roasted bone marrow - topped with a delicate lettuce leaf, each selected bone was a different height.  
2. the mustard celery was fantastic!!!! thinly sliced and "pickled" with mustard, i devoured this right up.
3. the veal kidneys with mushroom and house potatoes were excellent!  rich and filling.  this is a must try.
4. the veal liver with perfect fries and homemade mayo is not for the faint of heart.  this was quite a generous portion.  it would be something that i normally would not try but now, i would order it in a second.  the dish was packed full of flavor!

for dessert, we enjoyed a giant but light serving of the floating island - a lovely confection of whipped eggwhites with a sugar caramel crust topped with almond slices and floating on a sea of english cream.  it was the best one that i have ever sampled even compared to all the restos in paris.

fast and friendly service, this is a definite stop for anyone - local or just visiting.  be sure to look around as you may spot a local celebrity or two.

Wow! This place is amazing!!!! There was not a single thing that wasn't great! Recently went on a trip up to Montreal with a few friends and we decided to have a nice dinner and chose this place. So glad we did. If you are in the city, this is a must go to! Now onto the food.

Apps - 
Foie gras- I know this is controversial plate but wow. This was the best tasting foie gras I had and I had foie gras in Paris to compare. 

Bone marrow- I typically like the bone marrow that is broiled to have that crispy crust but this was still decadent and delicious

Octopus- if I had to choose, this was probably my least favorite ofthe three but still good nonetheless! 

Entree-

Quail- sooo so soooo good! Whatever the sauce was, it was amazing and the quail was so moist. The wild rice underneath also have a nice addition due to the texture. Everyone said they loved my dish the best

Steak tartar- this was also so good! Most steak tartar I've had, I feel like the ingredients they add overpower the steak a bit but this place it was perfect. Nothing over powered the flavor of the meat and it was nice and light and delicious 

Steak and frites- the steak was also on par with the fries. If you're not with group and great to try a bit of everything, I'd recommend going for another dish since steak and fries can be done elsewhere. 

Dessert

Originally my group wasn't planning to get dessert since we were stuff but the waiter brought out this amazing dish on the house! ( service was also amazing here. So friendly and knowledgeable) the outer crust was so sweet and delicious. Not sure what the inside was but it was nice and light. 

Next time I'm in down I am definitely stopping by this place again!

Should have noticed before choosing this place based on the Yelp reviews... that all but one on the first page was from a tourist. It was decent. Period. Not good or bad. Basic French staples done adequately. But every single person near us was a tourist. This isn't Paris people. If it were this place would be simply average among hundreds. We wanted a unique, local experience. This is an "I couldn't afford a vacation to Paris but I still want to feel like I ate at an average bistro in the 1st arr. I should have interpreted Yelp more dutifully.
Un incontournable montréalais!!! Tout est bon et le service est toujours de haute qualité.
One of the best meals I've ever had. Try the quail, and don't forget dessert.
Nice little restaurant with good food at fair prices. Love their pickles! The atmosphere is nice. Although their servers can come off not very approachable/friendly.

Great place to eat French cuisine.  We came to Montreal for great food and dinner, this place did not disappoint. I had hunger steak with fries and my wife got steak tartar and we both enjoyed  our food very much. Pleasant and professional personal. When we were there it was busy, we called ahead and made reservation, I advice you do the same to make sure you get seated right away. Will to here again next time I visit Montreal.

It was a lovely evening out here. The service was impeccable and attentive, and the food quite good. Wine is less expensive than other restaurants we tried, and the menu overall is reasonable (plates for $20-$30). We loved the gherkins and dijon mustard at the table, and the atmosphere was cozy. Would definitely go back!

This is an institution in Montreal in the french brasserie category, in fact it is one of the oldest (-+ 30 years).  The decor is great with it's high ceilings in a great french burgundy color, and a long bar, the front is all window, which let's in a lot of natural light and provides a view onto St Denis
.
The service here is top notch, very french so everything is quite smooth and attentive, it does have a touch of the old school snobyness at times, but generally speaking this is not a bad thing, they are not condencending just quite correct and maybe too formal.

The food is hit or miss for me, I will simply tell you what I really liked on my last visit
Os a Moelle, (it's a little pricey but if you have never tried this, do yourself a favor and start here), the fish soup is also very good and has a nice balance of flavors, on this last visit, (feb29,2012), I sample the octopus, which was boiled (as per waiter, which had me worried but I still ordered it), it was very tender to the taste and served over lentils, with onions and a vinegrette, a big winner. A goat cheese salad with endives followed and it was ok but nothing special, then a steak tartare, here we had a miss.  For me the texture (seriously ground to a mash), was so unappealing, and the flavors were too mild, barely anything other than capers, at 24$ with a choice of fries or mashed, this was the big let down.  
On the other hand the wines are great, they get all private imports which is ideal, we samples a gigondas 2008, costing 58$ that was very appreciated.

I have in the past been here for breakfast, which is rather limited but always good, it is not for those looking for bang for you buck or to fill up, but it is a very pleasant atmosphere.

They have really long hours and are often opened until 1-2am so if your looking for some quality noche, after hours this is a great alternative to crap food usually available at this time of night.
In short, go to L'Express. French-style bistro cuisine in a clean, bright, and bustling (but not too lively) atmosphere. The octopus salad and the profiteroles were immaculate!

L'Express provided an incredibly delicious and authentic French dinner. Everything that they brought to the table was delicious, including the steak tartare, octopus salad, and pot au fue. By far, my favorite dish was the shrimp risotto - if you like risotto, I highly recommend ordering this. A nice surprise was that the servings were a good size - my dinner partner and I both felt full after eating only an entree.

Additionally, the environment is very cozy, with wonderfully attentive service, and very fair prices. I can't wait to come back.

It was our last night in Montreal and we were really trying hard to find a nice place to eat...especially since the night before, we had the worst dining experience in years and years at Le Grille.  So we wanted some redemption.  We decided on L'Express.  What a great decision.  We walked in a little before 8 pm and the place was full.  The manager told us that they were booked with reservations and that we couldn't get a table until 10 pm or we could sit at the bar until 9 pm when another reservation was coming.  The manager was very polite and definitely accommodating given how busy it was that night.

The bartender greeted us warmly and was very attentive, even though the bar was completely full at this point.  We told him that we only had until 9 pm and then we had to give up the seats and he assured us not to worry and to enjoy our night.  We ordered a wonderful goat cheese salad, followed by hanger steak and roasted quail, both of which were fantastic.  Wonderful flavors throughout.  As we were finishing our wine, another bartender offered us the dessert menu, but since they did not have an English translation of that menu, he offered his help and explained the desserts to us.  We were both very impressed with how the bartenders were so kind and helpful.  

At this point, it had reached 9 pm and we thought we should leave but they assured us that it was no problem to have dessert so we did.  The chocolate dessert was absolutely wonderful.  We never felt rushed and we had a great experience.  

We would definitely go back next time.  And I would even rather sit at the bar then at a table.

One of the best establishments ive ever eaten at.  Living in NYC you think you know good food.  Not true until you have come to Montreal.  
Here we sat at the bar, had 100% top of the line service.  
We the octopus lentil salad which was outstanding.  Followed by the bone marrow, beautiful and rich, served piping hot.  Then on to steak frittes and followed with profitterioles.  Oh and a goat cheese salad.  
Everything was simple yet somehow elegant.  For instance they make there own mayo and the salt they use is grey celtic sea salt.  Also you are given fine olive oil at the table.  The little touches like fresh OJ  as a mixer in our drinks..  
Living in NYC there are many nice places to dine.  Lately it feels that your eating from a central kitchen with all the chefs being from Mexico city or something.  There is no authenticity anymore.  But here in Montreal true real french food is cooked by the french.  What a concept!  Italian food cooked by real Italians.  Bring it on.  Bring it all on.  
L' Express like many other great restuarants in Montreal have no outside signs indictating where you are eating and if you dont know exactly where it is you will not find it so get the address.  
Like i said the simple unspoiled elegance of this " fast good food" place is superb.  On weekends or early make sure you have reservations or you will wait a long time.  If its just 2 of you then reserve at the bar, the service is excellent and the seats comfortable.  
I love Montreal, what a beautiful city and wonderful people.  This place just puts the icing on the cake.  Moderate in priced too.

I love coming here with my family. This place just screams authenticity as a French bistro. 

Food: not once have we found something we didn't enjoy here. The food is simply fantastic. Be warned though, it's rather heavy and we sometimes have trouble unless we share appetizers.

Service: the staff is very kind and professional. Service is also fast and they were very accommodating with a last minute reservation too.

Price: more expensive than most meals but you're paying for quality here. It's definitely worth it.

Ambiance: I love how classy and authentic this place is. It has an old school vibe that's reflected in both the cuisine, and design.
